I'll be curious to see which jobs work?!"}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-06-08 16:55:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I spent some time trying to understand the functional test failure. I can reproduce it on my SAIO but not with same error message:

  swift@vm-16:~/swiftclient$ tox -e func -- tests.functional.test_swiftclient.TestFunctional.test_post_object
func develop-inst-nodeps: /home/swift/swiftclient
func installed: alabaster==0.7.10,Babel==2.6.0,certifi==2018.4.16,chardet==3.0.4,coverage==4.5.1,debtcollector==1.19.0,docutils==0.14,dulwich==0.19.2,extras==1.0.0,fixtures==3.0.0,flake8==2.2.4,hacking==0.10.3,idna==2.6,imagesize==1.0.0,iso8601==0.1.12,Jinja2==2.10,keystoneauth1==3.7.0,linecache2==1.0.0,MarkupSafe==1.0,mccabe==0.2.1,mock==2.0.0,monotonic==1.5,msgpack==0.5.6,netaddr==0.7.19,netifaces==0.10.7,openstackdocstheme==1.21.0,os-service-types==1.2.0,oslo.config==6.2.1,oslo.i18n==3.20.0,oslo.serialization==2.26.0,oslo.utils==3.36.2,oslosphinx==4.18.0,packaging==17.1,pbr==4.0.4,pep8==1.5.7,pyflakes==0.8.1,Pygments==2.2.0,pyparsing==2.2.0,python-keystoneclient==3.16.0,python-mimeparse==1.6.0,python-subunit==1.3.0,-e git+https://github.com/openstack/python-swiftclient.git@ff67c5b829795779fdd9687df01e54f621f8d2e2#egg=python_swiftclient,pytz==2018.4,PyYAML==3.12,reno==2.9.2,requests==2.18.4,rfc3986==1.1.0,six==1.11.0,snowballstemmer==1.2.1,Sphinx==1.7.5,sphinxcontrib-websupport==1.1.0,stevedore==1.28.0,testrepository==0.0.20,testtools==2.3.0,traceback2==1.4.0,unittest2==1.1.0,urllib3==1.22,wrapt==1.10.11
func runtests: PYTHONHASHSEED='2365868839'
func runtests: commands[0] | python setup.py testr --coverage --testr-args=--concurrency=1
running testr
running=${PYTHON:-python} -m subunit.run discover -t ./ ${OS_TEST_PATH:-./tests/unit}  
======================================================================
FAIL: tests.functional.test_swiftclient.TestFunctional.test_post_object
tags: worker-0
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/swift/swiftclient/tests/functional/test_swiftclient.py", line 417, in test_post_object
    headers.get('x-object-meta-uni'))
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/unittest/case.py", line 820, in assertEqual
    assertion_func(first, second, msg=msg)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/unittest/case.py", line 1193, in assertMultiLineEqual
    self.fail(self._formatMessage(msg, standardMsg))
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/unittest/case.py", line 665, in fail
    raise self.failureException(msg)
AssertionError: 'ت' != 'Øª'
- ت
+ Øª

FAILED (id=6, failures=1, skips=34)
error: testr failed (1)
ERROR: InvocationError: '/home/swift/swiftclient/.tox/func/bin/python setup.py testr --coverage --testr-args=--concurrency=1'

ت is bytes sent for the header value in the POST (b'\xd8\xaa'.decode('utf-8')), and wireshark confirms those bytes are returned with the HEAD response.

The header value coming out of requests response is Øª which is b'\xd8\xaa'.decode('latin-1') (note 'latin-1')

This almost certainly needs to be logged as a bug, I'm just not sure yet where the bug is - requests lib, swiftclient or the test itself. 

I'll try to dig further when I have more time.'}, {'account_id': 27153, 'date': '2018-06-11 08:27:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I86d24104033b490a35178fc504d88c1e4a566628
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-25 21:02:58.000000000', 'message': 'CentOS: Fix EPEL mirroring and RDO install on CI nodes

CentOS tests have reverted to using upstream for EPEL rather than
local mirrors, introducing some unnecessary instability.  The root of
the problem is that /etc/nodepool/provider disappeared with zuulv3, so
we now always re-install the EPEL repo and overwrite the local EPEL
.repos files that were made during test setup and point to local
mirrors.

The other change is that we stopped installing the RDO repositories on
the testing nodes too.  That we were incorrectly taking this path and
reinstalling EPEL has hidden the removal of these packages from the
base image in the test, since it ends up installing them too.

Split the install into two parts -- epel and RDO.  Check for
/etc/ci/mirror_info.sh (the sourcable mirror script provided by base
test setup) and if so, just enable EPEL so we get the CI-mirror
version correctly.  Install the RDO repositories (if not already
installed) unconditionally.

(Cherry-Picked from dc04b5aa24411b4081f0ad08021e0dc694c982e8)
Change-Id: Iccb045a6695deb10da4d68a5694e1fa45ccbb810
'}]
commit_message:
CentOS: Fix EPEL mirroring and RDO install on CI nodes

CentOS tests have reverted to using upstream for EPEL rather than
local mirrors, introducing some unnecessary instability.  The root of
the problem is that /etc/nodepool/provider disappeared with zuulv3, so
we now always re-install the EPEL repo and overwrite the local EPEL
.repos files that were made during test setup and point to local
mirrors.

The other change is that we stopped installing the RDO repositories on
the testing nodes too.  That we were incorrectly taking this path and
reinstalling EPEL has hidden the removal of these packages from the
base image in the test, since it ends up installing them too.

Split the install into two parts -- epel and RDO.  Check for
/etc/ci/mirror_info.sh (the sourcable mirror script provided by base
test setup) and if so, just enable EPEL so we get the CI-mirror
version correctly.  Install the RDO repositories (if not already
installed) unconditionally.

(Cherry-Picked from dc04b5aa24411b4081f0ad08021e0dc694c982e8)
Change-Id: Iccb045a6695deb10da4d68a5694e1fa45ccbb810

commit_message:
Drop unnecessary import

generate_uuid is only ever useful if you have code that needs to process
uuids also numerically. In our case it only adds indirection and another
source of dependency on oslo utils.

Change-Id: I92fbf002c2bd8c7a3fc7f7aee7d1197dc6a7dc87
Signed-off-by: Antoni Segura Puimedon <celebdor@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-01 19:37:19.000000000', 'message': 'dhcp: serializing port delete and network rpc calls

The port delete events are not synchronized with network rpc events.  This
creates a condition which makes it possible for a port delete event to be
processed just before a previously started network query completes.

The problematic order of operations is as follows:

  1) a network is scheduled to an agent; a network rpc is sent to the
     agent

  2) the agent queries the network data from the server

  3) while that query is in progress a port on that network is deleted; a
     port rpc is sent to the agent

  4) that port delete rpc is received before the network query rpc
     completes

  5) the port delete results in no action because the port was not present
     on the agent

  6) the network query finishes and adds the port to the cache (even
     though the port has already been deleted)

  7) some time passes and a new port is configured with the same IP
     address as the port that was deleted in (3)

  8) the dhcp host file is corrupted with 2 entries for the same IP
     address.

  9) dhcp queries for the newest port is rejected because of the duplicate
     entry in the dhcp host file.

The solution is to add the network_id to the port_delete_end rpc event
so that the _net_lock(network_id) synchronization point can be acquired
so that it is processed serially with other network related events.

To ensure backwards compatibility with newer agents running against older
servers the determination of which network_id value to use in the lock is
handled using a utility that will fallback to the previous mode of operation
whenever the network_id attribute is not present in the *_delete_end RPC
events.  That utility can be removed in the future when it is guaranteed
that the network_id attribute will be present in RPC messages from the
server.

Closes-Bug: #1732456

Change-Id: I735f8b1c9248b12e5feb6cbe970cf67f321e6ebc
Signed-off-by: Allain Legacy <allain.legacy@windriver.com>
'}, {'created': '2017-12-04 17:44:48.000000000', 'message': 'dhcp: serializing port delete and network rpc calls

     on the agent

  6) the network query finishes and adds the port to the cache (even
     though the port has already been deleted)

  7) some time passes and a new port is configured with the same IP
     address as the port that was deleted in (3)

  8) the dhcp host file is corrupted with 2 entries for the same IP
     address.

  9) dhcp queries for the newest port is rejected because of the duplicate
     entry in the dhcp host file.

The solution is to add the network_id to the port_delete_end rpc event
so that the _net_lock(network_id) synchronization point can be acquired
so that it is processed serially with other network related events.

To ensure backwards compatibility with newer agents running against older
servers the determination of which network_id value to use in the lock is
handled using a utility that will fallback to the previous mode of operation
whenever the network_id attribute is not present in the *_delete_end RPC
events.  That utility can be removed in the future when it is guaranteed
that the network_id attribute will be present in RPC messages from the
server.

Closes-Bug: #1732456

Change-Id: I735f8b1c9248b12e5feb6cbe970cf67f321e6ebc
Signed-off-by: Allain Legacy <allain.legacy@windriver.com>

commit_message:
dhcp: serializing port delete and network rpc calls

The port delete events are not synchronized with network rpc events.  This
creates a condition which makes it possible for a port delete event to be
processed just before a previously started network query completes.

The problematic order of operations is as follows:

  1) a network is scheduled to an agent; a network rpc is sent to the
     agent

  2) the agent queries the network data from the server

  3) while that query is in progress a port on that network is deleted; a
     port rpc is sent to the agent

  4) that port delete rpc is received before the network query rpc
     completes

  5) the port delete results in no action because the port was not present
     on the agent

  6) the network query finishes and adds the port to the cache (even
     though the port has already been deleted)

  7) some time passes and a new port is configured with the same IP
     address as the port that was deleted in (3)

  8) the dhcp host file is corrupted with 2 entries for the same IP
     address.

  9) dhcp queries for the newest port is rejected because of the duplicate
     entry in the dhcp host file.

The solution is to add the network_id to the port_delete_end rpc event
so that the _net_lock(network_id) synchronization point can be acquired
so that it is processed serially with other network related events.

To ensure backwards compatibility with newer agents running against older
servers the determination of which network_id value to use in the lock is
handled using a utility that will fallback to the previous mode of operation
whenever the network_id attribute is not present in the *_delete_end RPC
events.  That utility can be removed in the future when it is guaranteed
that the network_id attribute will be present in RPC messages from the
server.

Closes-Bug: #1732456

Change-Id: I735f8b1c9248b12e5feb6cbe970cf67f321e6ebc
Signed-off-by: Allain Legacy <allain.legacy@windriver.com>

commit_message:
Add simple validation that OpenShift is deployed

Currently, we have no test to check if we actually deploy OpenShift
at the end of the scenario009 job. This can easily lead to false
positives from this job if some deploy step fails silently.

This patch adds two very basic commands to check if the OpenShift
cluster is actually operational.

Depends-On: Ibe94a58e0083b75e2f4cc904be6c17b0633d0293
Depends-On: Id24a7a0d9d34df4fd52ee1f99da61b873e5b870a
Depends-On: Ie21cc0dfed28353a13d419ff38cea82e65166221

Change-Id: Iee477ea736aff4290b703cd70258966819228c4a

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-10 21:49:51.000000000', 'message': "Unit tests: Fix mock errors with too few side effects

When a mock hasn't been provided with a long-enough list of side-effects
for the number of times it is called, it raises StopIteration (instead
of something sensible like AssertionError). Prior to Python 3.7, this
exception could bubble up until it just stopped a task. (In Python 3.7
it will eventually be caught and turned into a RuntimeError.)

To ensure that any errors of this sort are not handled silently, and to
enable us to test for them prior to using Python 3.7, catch any
StopIteration errors coming from plugin-provided non-generator functions
and convert them to RuntimeError exceptions.

This reveals many errors in the unit tests, which are also fixed by this
patch. This backport contains fewer fixes than master, because many of
the errors were introduced in the process of moving from mox to mock in
the Rocky release cycle.

Change-Id: I5a1eff6b704dff7c17edcbbe58cdbc380ae6abc9
Story: #2003412
Task: 24553
(cherry picked from commit 38fad07c0a01072ee4e17815f6ad0e5c2ce1f64a)
"}]
commit_message:
Unit tests: Fix mock errors with too few side effects

When a mock hasn't been provided with a long-enough list of side-effects
for the number of times it is called, it raises StopIteration (instead
of something sensible like AssertionError). Prior to Python 3.7, this
exception could bubble up until it just stopped a task. (In Python 3.7
it will eventually be caught and turned into a RuntimeError.)

To ensure that any errors of this sort are not handled silently, and to
enable us to test for them prior to using Python 3.7, catch any
StopIteration errors coming from plugin-provided non-generator functions
and convert them to RuntimeError exceptions.

This reveals many errors in the unit tests, which are also fixed by this
patch. This backport contains fewer fixes than master, because many of
the errors were introduced in the process of moving from mox to mock in
the Rocky release cycle.

Change-Id: I5a1eff6b704dff7c17edcbbe58cdbc380ae6abc9
Story: #2003412
Task: 24553
(cherry picked from commit 38fad07c0a01072ee4e17815f6ad0e5c2ce1f64a)

a VM it may happen that an old ARP entry may persist. If you create
another VM with the same IP and the arp update goes to the other
router you have a VM which isn't reachable via one router since the
ARP entry is wrong.

commit_message:
Consider all router ports for dvr arp updates.

If you have a subnet with 2 routers and you create and then delete
a VM it may happen that an old ARP entry may persist. If you create
another VM with the same IP and the arp update goes to the other
router you have a VM which isn't reachable via one router since the
ARP entry is wrong.
This fixes this issue by simply iterating over all router ports
and generating the respective messages for the l3 agents to
handle.

Change-Id: Ie17e94bc2d27b4c5171b318e20a8e968b9cffebb
Closes-Bug: #1794535

commit_message:
[ZFSOnLinux] Retry unmounting old datasets during manage

Add a retry loop to ensure the dataset being renamed
is cleanly unmounted before the rename operation.

Change-Id: Ie506f237010c415ee9f0d64abbefd5854f776a5f
Closes-Bug: #1785180
(cherry picked from commit d7c01efb444b7bf02c1729be3554abebaee473a3)
(cherry picked from commit 6d8f47d3c367aa0247dca713146825cfa66b6848)
(cherry picked from commit 820638ccef471eb00f2a233e64b05a9c377e170c)

(14 comments)

Eliminating DiskfileRouter is a laudable goal, but I think it may be a step too far. The DiskFileRouter served three purposes:

1. a place for diskfile manager to register themselves. That needs to go away and be replaced by entry point lookup from policy config.

2. a place to hold conf and logger values for a specific set of diskfile manager instances i.e. like a configurable diskfile manager factory.

3. a cache of per-policy diskfile manager instances

Losing 2 results in the weird interface to policy.load_diskfile_manager(conf, logger) where conf and logger may be ignored and the subsequent call to policy.diskfile_manager returns a diskfile manager with a different conf and logger. This is subtle and risky is a process ever expects multiple *differently configured* diskfile managers for the same policy (note: config includes the logger).

In the unit tests it creates havoc, because in the unit tests we definitely create multiple diskfile managers for same policy (e.g. in test_ssync).

I suspect that if we retain DiskfileRouter with same __getitem__ interface then this patch will get a lot simpler, a lot of the test churn will disappear, and we avoid inadvertently using the wrong diskfile manager config and logger.

I put some ideas for a new DiskfileRouter here [1] and other less controversial fixes here [2]. Take anything you like from either. However, before making large changes like [1] to this patch we should probably try to get some consensus to avoid ping-pong patches.


[1] https://gist.github.com/alistairncoles
/352b1f9f047eb72129bec2e7c7cededd
[2] https://review.openstack.org/573309'}, {'account_id': 25251, 'date': '2018-06-29 15:28:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 25251, 'date': '2018-06-29 15:30:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 25251, 'date': '2018-06-29 15:35:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

I took Alistair's suggestion (https://gist.github.com/alistairncoles/352b1f9f047eb72129bec2e7c7cededd)
Keeping DiskFileRouter and its interface makes for a much smaller patch."}, {'account_id': 25251, 'date': '2018-07-02 13:19:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 25251, 'date': '2018-07-02 13:22:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 25251, 'date': '2018-07-02 16:01:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-07-03 15:04:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-07-03 15:04:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-07-03 15:09:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: Code-Review+2

I think this warrants more than one +2 because it is a significant change that does not yet have a use case (although we know that LOSF is one future use case). I'll add it to a swift meeting agenda to get opinions on merging without the immediate use case.

Also, I have had a hand in authoring this."}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-07-03 18:01:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2018-07-03 20:56:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

I certainly haven't looked at this enough to give a real review, but i love the idea.

Alistair, I'm not too worried about the "no uses yet", when we've already got 2 uses in our codebase today. We also know we want LOSF (and stuff like it), so even if that doesn't land for a long time, it removes barriers for getting that sort of new functionality.

Not having run the patch yet, just looking at it in gerrit, it looks ok'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-07-05 10:35:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review+2

LGTM but other core(s) should approve - I have authored some of this.'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2018-07-24 08:26:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

In my brief look, the code change looks reasonable and it seems to work (I tried just to restart the server with this configuration tho) but some points in the configuration seems to need the design decision if we should follow the middleware declaration format.

Following the format may be intuitive but on the other hand some of values like scheme is meaningless for now that may confuse the new Swift operators.

I leave my soft -1 here to get ideas how authors think about that so if the idea sounds reasonable to me, I'm willing turn my score to positive value."}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2018-07-25 02:11:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

Added Thiago who maintains swift-on-file that is a diskfile extension to support another file system than xfs. He may have any ideas how the configuration helps us more generic.'}, {'account_id': 14766, 'date': '2018-07-25 04:34:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review-1

(11 comments)

After I looked at all parts in this patch, to be honest, I'd like to add my +2 for this awesome work but the only one thing blocks me to do that. The thing is regression (around error message from DiskFileManager.check_policy) from patch set 16 that makes obviously confuse the operators. Other minor nits are acceptable to me at this moment.

Including all minor fixes, I pushed a follow up at [1], please check out that and my inline comments.

Thanks,

(2 comments)

You'd think the guy that wrote this actually runs swift clusters or something.

FWIW as an author/maintainer of kinetic-swift [1] - I'm happy with Swift moving this direction in principle.  I think it makes diskfile plugin authors' lives better in the long run even if there's some growing pains if/when people using plugins want to update to the latest swift version.

AFAIK most diskfile plugins already pin swift compatibility, so aside from some code churn it's unlikely to cause any more of a problem than other minor breakage in compatibility we've had in the past.

1. https://github.com/swiftstack/kinetic-swift"}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2018-09-26 05:55:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 20: Code-Review+2

(2 comments)

Nice work, had a play with it, made my own diskfile implementation, which was almost exactly like replication, just slightly changed so I could see this patch work.

There is a problem on the commit message but not going to make that a blocker. More of a NIT (ie if we need to reroll the patch)

I do have another NIT. but nothing as a blocker and really is only my own personal preference :)

Wont +A yet in case we're waiting to hear back from the gluster people. I'll let someone do the honours tomorrow in the meeting ;)"}, {'account_id': 25251, 'date': '2018-09-26 14:27:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 20:

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-03-17 20:38:22.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Configure diskfile per storage policy

With this commit, each storage policy can define the diskfile to use to
access objects. Configuration of the diskfile is done in swift.conf.

Example:
    [storage-policy:0]
    name = gold
    policy_type = replication
    default = yes

    diskfile = replication.fs
    diskfile.devices = /srv/1/node
    diskfile.mount_check = false
    diskfile.disable_fallocate = true

It even allows for different storage policy to use different
configuration for the same diskfile (eg: keep_cache_size, reclaim_age,
...)

The DiskFileRouter is removed. The DiskFileManager is now accessed through
the policy instance:
    df_router[policy].get_diskfile(...)
become:
    policy.diskfile_manager.get_diskfile(...)

FIXME: it breaks SAIO as configuration parameter "devices"
(eg: /srv/1/node) is now in swift.conf, but there can't be one swift.conf
per object-server instance

Change-Id: I070c21bc1eaf1c71ac0652cec9e813cadcc14851
'}, {'created': '2017-03-20 17:49:20.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Configure diskfile per storage policy

    policy_type = replication
    default = yes
    diskfile = replication.fs

The DiskFileRouter is removed. The DiskFileManager is now accessed through

become:

    policy.diskfile_manager

Change-Id: I070c21bc1eaf1c71ac0652cec9e813cadcc14851
'}, {'created': '2017-09-13 21:04:06.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Configure diskfile per storage policy

With this commit, each storage policy can define the diskfile to use to
access objects. Selection of the diskfile is done in swift.conf.

Example:
    [storage-policy:0]
    name = gold
    policy_type = replication
    default = yes
    diskfile = egg:swift#replication.fs

The diskfile configuration item accepts the same format than middlewares
declaration: [[scheme:]egg_name#]entry_point
The egg_name is optional and default to "swift". The scheme is optional
and default to the only valid value "egg". The upstream entry points are
"replication.fs" and "erasure_coding.fs".

The DiskFileRouter is removed. The DiskFileManager is now accessed through
the policy instance:
    df_router[policy].get_diskfile(...)
become:
    policy.load_diskfile_manager(conf, logger)
    policy.diskfile_manager

Change-Id: I070c21bc1eaf1c71ac0652cec9e813cadcc14851

Co-Authored-By: Alexandre Lécuyer <alexandre.lecuyer@corp.ovh.com>
Co-Authored-By: Alistair Coles <alistairncoles@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I070c21bc1eaf1c71ac0652cec9e813cadcc14851
'}]
commit_message:
Configure diskfile per storage policy

With this commit, each storage policy can define the diskfile to use to
access objects. Selection of the diskfile is done in swift.conf.

Example:
    [storage-policy:0]
    name = gold
    policy_type = replication
    default = yes
    diskfile = egg:swift#replication.fs

The diskfile configuration item accepts the same format than middlewares
declaration: [[scheme:]egg_name#]entry_point
The egg_name is optional and default to "swift". The scheme is optional
and default to the only valid value "egg". The upstream entry points are
"replication.fs" and "erasure_coding.fs".

Co-Authored-By: Alexandre Lécuyer <alexandre.lecuyer@corp.ovh.com>
Co-Authored-By: Alistair Coles <alistairncoles@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I070c21bc1eaf1c71ac0652cec9e813cadcc14851

the task will fail.

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 29203, 'date': '2018-09-26 23:12:55.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Switch to origin-docker-build

Since OpenShift 3.10, origin-sti-build is deprecated in favor of
origin-docker-builder:

https://github.com/openshift/origin/commit/57e7c6c0d45fb7f7b2e4bb6dfc13ad5b4b46d0b9

The new heat parameter for the image is now
DockerOpenShiftDockerBuilderImage.

Change-Id: I46def282e9bd2fd84322c8b9213ac280782f09dd

commit_message:
Set containerized_undercloud for OpenShift featureset

We are getting most of the behaviors of containerized_undercloud
when using containerized_undercloud=false (default). Namely, the
undercloud is deployed via containers.

However, without this explicity set, we do not include the
containers-prepare-parameter.yaml in the undercloud.conf template[1].

This causes the undercloud containers to never be updated since the
update params are templated to that file.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras/blob/b3794ff03ab841bbbc15a339e35a7ec02b193111/roles/undercloud-deploy/templates/undercloud.conf.j2#L260-L266
Change-Id: Ibe94a58e0083b75e2f4cc904be6c17b0633d0293

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be

commit_message:
Add config option endpoint_type for designate

Designate client can only use publicURL as default endpoint type when neutron
uses designate as an external dns driver, add this option to use adminURL or
internalURL as the endpoint type. The option endpoint_type can be configured
in neutron.conf as follows.
[designate]:
endpoint_type=publicURL, adminURL or internalURL

Closes-bug: #1756291
Change-Id: I2969f2adfc648787ffa5446f1e3d4b286306ac1e

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2018-09-25 21:10:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> is this absolutely necessary?  it would make future sync difficult
 > and tedious.

IMO, there are several reasons that makes this change necessary:

* We want to avoid colliding with the namespace of the old library. If both libraries use the same namespace, we might hit several problems on importing which we want to avoid.
* The convention is to have the namespace the same or similar as the repo name and this change follow this convention.'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2018-09-26 15:13:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 21798, 'date': '2018-09-26 15:18:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Move files from ryu/* to os_ken/*

After forking from Ryu, the namespace needs to change from 'ryu'
to 'os_ken' so that it won't collide with the namespace of the
old library.

Change-Id: I807a8785e525cc02825d15a1a01eec3d5d20cce4

commit_message:
MNAIO: Fix file-backed VM deployment

Recent patches broke the file-backed VM deployment.
This patch fixes it again. It also ensures that the
cleanup of VM's removes any VM's running, rather than
the active inventory.

Change-Id: Ic1cc887bf61162a8c8d96dd53f6db9583c4c089b

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-09-26 13:10:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I can change it...

The reason I've been focusing on "Docs" is that the tooltip only says "Docs home", so we have two options:

1/ Customize the whole title and reuse the title in the tooltip (making it "OpenStack Docs home", and therefore the change is not a noop for docs.o.o)

2/ Creating two theme options, one to customize "OpenStack" and one to customize "Docs". That sounds really overkill.

I'll implement (1) unless you tell me otherwise.
issue here is that it will change the tooltip (from "Docs home" to "OpenStack Docs home"'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-09-26 13:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-09-26 13:53:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> I can change it...

 > says "Docs home", so we have two options:
 > 
 > 1/ Customize the whole title and reuse the title in the tooltip
 > (making it "OpenStack Docs home", and therefore the change is not a
 > noop for docs.o.o)
 > 
 > 2/ Creating two theme options, one to customize "OpenStack" and one
 > to customize "Docs". That sounds really overkill.
 > 
 > I'll implement (1) unless you tell me otherwise.
 > issue here is that it will change the tooltip (from "Docs home" to

Yup, (1) would be my preferred solution too. No point making things more difficult that they have to be and OpenStack Docs home makes more sense (to me, at least)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-09-26 13:55:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

We need to rework that "configuration options" section to be more like a definition list, but that's clearly unrelated. This looks much better to me'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-09-26 14:04:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Make root title customizable

The theme displays "OpenStack Docs:" in the title and "Docs home"
in the tooltip, which makes it hard to reuse for other websites
(including the governance website). This patch makes the root title
("OpenStack Docs" by default) configurable.

Change-Id: I4140f62a328debf81703cddd17dd6364b5eab479

subject: Add Octavia to global requirements
messages:
[{'account_id': 13438, 'date': '2018-08-01 14:21:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20363, 'date': '2018-08-01 16:00:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-08-01 16:26:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

we are in the freeze period, please submit a ffe request to the os-dev list with a subject prefixed with [ffe][requirements].

having said that, what project is using octavia as a library?  I'm fairly sure we try VERY hard to avoid such usage."}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-08-01 16:48:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

if you wish to use octavia as a library, create octavia-lib and move the common functions/classes there.'}, {'account_id': 13438, 'date': '2018-08-02 07:14:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Beginning Rocky, Octavia offers a driver model for LB vendors. Any vendor who would like to integrate a driver from his own repo will need this dependency - VMware happened to be the 1st.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-08-02 13:26:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Beginning Rocky, Octavia offers a driver model for LB vendors. Any
 > vendor who would like to integrate a driver from his own repo will
 > need this dependency - VMware happened to be the 1st.

Octavia is being published to PyPI, so I see no issue with adding it to the dependency list to make it easier for third-party testing.

The current validation error is happening because this patch also needs to include a version for Octavia in the upper-constraints.txt file. Today the highest version that could be used is 2.0.1, but based on your comment above I doubt that is what anyone actually wants. I suggest waiting until after the final Rocky release is completed and then using 3.0.0.

I also think the Octavia team should consider switching the release model from cycle-with-milestones to cycle-with-intermediary so they can publish updates more often.

And of course we shouldn't approve the change until after we branch the requirements list for Rocky."}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-08-02 14:18:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Why would we switch release models? We have no driver to release more often or drop from the milestone releases. I think we would only consider that if neutron, nova, and glance do so.

I don't have a problem with adding it, as I see neutron is included in the GR list.
That said, I'm not sure I understand the need for this. The driver package should be able to include Octavia in the requirements.txt of the driver package."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-08-02 14:29:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Why would we switch release models? We have no driver to release
 > more often or drop from the milestone releases. I think we would
 > only consider that if neutron, nova, and glance do so.
 > 
 > I don't have a problem with adding it, as I see neutron is included
 > in the GR list.
 > That said, I'm not sure I understand the need for this. The driver
 > package should be able to include Octavia in the requirements.txt
 > of the driver package.

Pre-release versions like betas can't be installed by pip without special instructions. So without intermediate releases in the middle of a cycle, driver authors will be stuck waiting for the final release before they can test and update their projects."}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-08-02 15:20:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

ya, was just going to mention the release model thing, it's generally a rule that libraries (which it sounds like octavia has become...) need that for the reason doug mentioned (releases during the cycle, beta, rc) cannot be installed by normal methods.  This would interfere with development of stuff dependant on octavia.

Again, I highly recommend that anyone wishing to use a service as a library push for the creation of $service-lib.  That way the service and the plugin can just depend on an actual library instead of having something try to provide both functions."}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-08-02 15:22:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This is not how we handle drivers for neutron today, so why would octavia be different?
They install via setuptools entry point and have a defined interface.
I don't see why this requires a change in release cadence unless we do that to all of the OpenStack services.
They are not importing our code aside from a callback that is an interim solution until we decide on the security approach for the driver endpoint, at which point that goes away too."}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-08-02 15:23:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Absolutely NOT. Octavia is not a library and does not support or encourage that.
Who said it was?'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-08-02 16:24:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> This is not how we handle drivers for neutron today, so why would
 > octavia be different?
 > They install via setuptools entry point and have a defined
 > interface.
 > I don't see why this requires a change in release cadence unless we
 > do that to all of the OpenStack services.
 > They are not importing our code aside from a callback that is an
 > interim solution until we decide on the security approach for the
 > driver endpoint, at which point that goes away too.

Because the testing situation with neutron is terrible. We spend a lot of time and effort making the CI system handle special cases for unit tests for things that depend on neutron and horizon."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-08-02 16:26:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Absolutely NOT. Octavia is not a library and does not support or
 > encourage that.
 > Who said it was?

The only reason to include Octavia here is to allow a project to express a dependency on it. If a driver imports Octavia code, that makes that part of Octavia a library. If the Octavia team doesn't want to extract that into its own library, then the releases for the service need to be treated as libraries (i.e., when a new feature is available, prepare a release so drivers can depend on that new version). So Octavia itself isn't a library, but we need to treat it as one for testing purposes."}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-08-02 16:37:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Yeah, Octavia is not a library and has no intentions of becoming one.

I am -1 because this project is not a library and should not be treated as one. There should not be any confusion over that.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-08-03 00:53:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Yeah, Octavia is not a library and has no intentions of becoming
 > one.
 > 
 > I am -1 because this project is not a library and should not be
 > treated as one. There should not be any confusion over that.

OK. I expect the Octavia team is going to need to become familiar with the byzantine ways the neutron and horizon plugins/drivers are tested so you can support the folks writing drivers for those projects. You can talk to the infra team about what's needed."}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-08-15 21:15:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-08-15 21:18:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

still very against this, but we are out of the FFE period'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-09-26 21:04:47.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

abandoned with johnsom's ack"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-01 14:21:39.000000000', 'message': 'Add Octavia to global requirements

Octavia project is missing from global requirements while vmware-nsx
is not dependant on it.

Change-Id: I0e3364265511aea9a0757fc8d42e05fdf9817f1e
'}]
commit_message:
Add Octavia to global requirements

Octavia project is missing from global requirements while vmware-nsx
is not dependant on it.

Change-Id: I0e3364265511aea9a0757fc8d42e05fdf9817f1e

commit_message:
Ignore VirtDriverNotReady in _sync_power_states periodic task

Change Ib0ec1012b74e9a9e74c8879f3feed5f9332b711f introduced
a new VirtDriverNotReady exception which the ironic driver raises
when asked to retrieve a list of nodes and ironic-api is not
available, like if nova-compute is started before ironic-api.
This is normal and meant to be self-healing, but we can get it
in other periodic tasks besides update_available_resource which
leads to ugly exception traces on startup in the logs. This adds
handling for the exception in the _sync_power_states periodic
task.

Change-Id: Iaf29b9e7a92705ac8a2e7ef338b92f7f1203506d
Closes-Bug: #1793768

commit_message:
Get glance v1 client for icehouse.

Previously the image virt type was qemu and the compute node virt
type was kvm. This works for deployments prior to rocky but in
rocky this causes the image type filter to return no valid hosts.
An update to charmhelpers has removed the default behaviour of
setting the virt type to 'qemu' by default.

Due to a bug in icehouse updating glance image properties using
the v2 api fails (See Bug #1371559) so for icehouse deploys
get a v1 client.

Change-Id: I20548118092a4480f37c7ab7e9d60e72e299989b

[{'created': '2018-09-21 19:35:46.000000000', 'message': 'fix: Re-clarify unit test REVIEWING documentation

This patch set corrects some misleading documentation under "Unit
Tests" section in REVIEWING.rst.

It currently claims that service clients do not require unit test
coverage -- but this is false. This is because Tempest now places
all of its service clients in tempest.lib. And as per
https://docs.openstack.org/tempest/latest/library.html#testing it
is required to add unit tests for all service client interfaces.

Thus this makes the documentation language clear that service clients
require unit tests.

Change-Id: Iac6ba71496e20b6724a6a2ca4ec2beb42f2a58c8
'}]
commit_message:
fix: Re-clarify unit test REVIEWING documentation

This patch set corrects some misleading documentation under "Unit
Tests" section in REVIEWING.rst.

It currently claims that service clients do not require unit test
coverage -- but this is false. This is because Tempest now places
all of its service clients in tempest.lib. And as per
https://docs.openstack.org/tempest/latest/library.html#testing it
is required to add unit tests for all service client interfaces.

Thus this makes the documentation language clear that service clients
require unit tests.

Change-Id: Iac6ba71496e20b6724a6a2ca4ec2beb42f2a58c8

[{'created': '2018-09-25 21:07:41.000000000', 'message': 'api-ref: add 'migrations' param to GET /os-migrations

The response parameter table for the GET /os-migrations
API reference was missing the top level "migrations"
parameter which is the list of migration objects.

While in here, fix the fake "Done" status to "done"
in the sample. There is nothing in nova that uses a
status of "Done". The evacuate operation uses "done".

Change-Id: I1e193237e9aec05395cd2760d96e70db7791409b
'}]
commit_message:
api-ref: add 'migrations' param to GET /os-migrations

The response parameter table for the GET /os-migrations
API reference was missing the top level "migrations"
parameter which is the list of migration objects.

While in here, fix the fake "Done" status to "done"
in the sample. There is nothing in nova that uses a
status of "Done". The evacuate operation uses "done".

Change-Id: I1e193237e9aec05395cd2760d96e70db7791409b

cells: Be explicit in docs about service restarts

imcomplete setup. Just adding a clear note on the dependency.

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-12-13 16:20:45.000000000', 'message': 'Transform missing delete notifications

The XXX patch only considered instance delete in the happy case
when the instance is scheduled to a compute successfully and the
compute is available when the delete action is executed.
If the instance is never scheduled to a compute or the compute
is not available when the instance is deleted legacy delete
notifications are emitted from different places, compute.api instead of
compute.manager. The original patch missed these places.

There will be subsequent patch(es) handling the same edge cases
for soft_delete and force_delete.

Change-Id: If0693eab2ed31b5fbfe6cbafa5d67b69c2ed8442
Implements: bp versioned-notification-transformation-ocata

compute successfully and the compute is available when the delete
action is executed. If the instance is never scheduled to a compute or
the compute is not available when the instance is deleted legacy delete
notifications are emitted from different places, compute.api instead of
compute.manager. The original patch missed these places.

There will be subsequent patch(es) handling the same edge cases
for soft_delete and force_delete.

Change-Id: If0693eab2ed31b5fbfe6cbafa5d67b69c2ed8442
Implements: bp versioned-notification-transformation-rocky

commit_message:
Transform missing delete notifications

The Iddbe50ce0ad3c14562df800bbc09ec5a7e840485 patch only considered
instance delete in the happy case when the instance is scheduled to a
compute successfully and the compute is available when the delete
action is executed. If the instance is never scheduled to a compute or
the compute is not available when the instance is deleted legacy delete
notifications are emitted from different places, compute.api instead of
compute.manager. The original patch missed these places.

There will be subsequent patch(es) handling the same edge cases
for soft_delete and force_delete.

Change-Id: If0693eab2ed31b5fbfe6cbafa5d67b69c2ed8442
Implements: bp versioned-notification-transformation-stein

commit_message:
Set different branch in zuul_changes

* If "zuul_changes": "testproject:master:refs/changes/42/13942/1^
  openstack/manila:stable/pike:refs/changes/71/603171/3^
  testproject:master:refs/changes/43/13943/36" in this format that time
  the zuul_deps checks for branch needs to be equal to changed branch
  but sometime different branch is also used to test stuff that it is
  ignored, it fixes the same.

Change-Id: I024cdc4f0e18ec7bce77d677e44cd0efcb60588e

[{'created': '2018-09-25 17:12:49.000000000', 'message': 'Remove broken uptime tests during upgrade

The uptime tests during upgrades have not been
working for some time, and we really need a better
way to implement them anyway.

To at least allow upgrade tests to work without
their interference, we remove the scripts and
implementation.

Change-Id: I33f7994a50ba5fcea7fca171dfca6b4d32011900
(cherry picked from commit 889e0599098e479b9d5a580a81a928ec39186047)
'}]
commit_message:
Remove broken uptime tests during upgrade

The uptime tests during upgrades have not been
working for some time, and we really need a better
way to implement them anyway.

To at least allow upgrade tests to work without
their interference, we remove the scripts and
implementation.

Change-Id: I33f7994a50ba5fcea7fca171dfca6b4d32011900
(cherry picked from commit 889e0599098e479b9d5a580a81a928ec39186047)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-06 13:11:12.000000000', 'message': 'Make using trusts for action execution optional

Adds a configuration flag to opt out from using trusts for all
action executions.

Remark: this is required in cases when the target cloud is accessed
using Keystone V2 authentication.

Change-Id: I6c546f5f219e9df6df3feebe2559cb4075e37510
'}]
commit_message:
Make using trusts for action execution optional

Adds a configuration flag to opt out from using trusts for all
action executions.

Remark: this is required in cases when the target cloud is accessed
using Keystone V2 authentication.

Change-Id: I6c546f5f219e9df6df3feebe2559cb4075e37510

The mnaio_hosts group is redundant. We switch to just using the
vm_hosts group instead.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-25 17:11:31.000000000', 'message': 'Remove broken uptime tests during upgrade

The uptime tests during upgrades have not been
working for some time, and we really need a better
way to implement them anyway.

To at least allow upgrade tests to work without
their interference, we remove the scripts and
implementation.

Change-Id: I33f7994a50ba5fcea7fca171dfca6b4d32011900

commit_message:
Remove broken uptime tests during upgrade

The uptime tests during upgrades have not been
working for some time, and we really need a better
way to implement them anyway.

To at least allow upgrade tests to work without
their interference, we remove the scripts and
implementation.

Change-Id: I33f7994a50ba5fcea7fca171dfca6b4d32011900
(cherry picked from commit 889e0599098e479b9d5a580a81a928ec39186047)

commit_message:
Specify domain when looking up heat user

The domain-setup action checks if the heat domain, user and roles
are setup before creating them, but in the case of the user it
was not checking the users existence in the correct domain.

Change-Id: I6998fe0543b26232c65c43bc9b2a8cc4b20bcbc5
Closes-Bug: #1793170
(cherry picked from commit e8354a1b6804bb2fcf091dc12cc50a753f561a86)

subject: Add template param for ambari pkg install timeout
messages: [{'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2018-09-25 20:18:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26181, 'date': '2018-09-26 02:59:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2018-09-26 16:06:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2018-09-26 17:38:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-25 20:18:27.000000000', 'message': 'Add template param for ambari pkg install timeout

Often time ambari fails during cluster installation/service
starting stage. This is quiet prominent when  there is
a large number of nodes in the cluster. Review of the
logs from the cluster indicates that ambari installation
scripts has a timeout parameter set to 1800 sec, this
requires adjustment depending on the environment and
speed of package installation.

This fix provides one parameter named
"agent.package.install.task.timeout"  inside the Ambari tab
of the HDP cluster template UI . User may change the
values and accordingly the ambari server will be setup
for package installation timeout.'

Change-Id: I826dbebb446d49e01e3cd6d7e525b43aa4523434
Story: #2003176
Task: #23320
(cherry picked from commit e7a4b58c5a638a422540f19e5d34d4f9d84a9c93)
'}]
commit_message:
Add template param for ambari pkg install timeout

Often time ambari fails during cluster installation/service
starting stage. This is quiet prominent when  there is
a large number of nodes in the cluster. Review of the
logs from the cluster indicates that ambari installation
scripts has a timeout parameter set to 1800 sec, this
requires adjustment depending on the environment and
speed of package installation.

This fix provides one parameter named
"agent.package.install.task.timeout"  inside the Ambari tab
of the HDP cluster template UI . User may change the
values and accordingly the ambari server will be setup
for package installation timeout.'

Change-Id: I826dbebb446d49e01e3cd6d7e525b43aa4523434
Story: #2003176
Task: #23320
(cherry picked from commit e7a4b58c5a638a422540f19e5d34d4f9d84a9c93)

commit_message:
VMAX driver - Block revert to snapshot for replicated volumes

Attempting to restore a replicated volume to snapshot will result in an
error, as this operation requires the RDF relationship to be suspended
first. It would be safest to throw an exception and block this operation
on replicated volumes. The user could instead create a new volume from
the snapshot and attach that, instead of reverting the original volume.
This patch implements this change.

Change-Id: If7b1dc408375d724fdc9ce6a3e256ad37e7c946f
Closes-bug: 1777871
(cherry picked from commit 92fbe37087f75ac698e39f2fd635caefac1a4e6d)

commit_message:
Start websocket client before workflows

When we start a workflow in the client, we need to create the websocket
connection beforehand. If the workflow is very quick (like
create_overcloudrc), it could be finished before we subscribe to the
Zaqar queue properly, and thus we wouldn't get the message.

Change-Id: I56c5f3a094094f7ba2158d8a434122ccb496f6b4
Closes-Bug: #1794418

[{'created': '2018-09-25 19:24:00.000000000', 'message': 'opt in for neutron-lib consumption patches

As part of the Denver PTG [1] we decided networking related projects
that are "current" and want to receive neutron-lib consumption patches
on an on-going basis should indicate such with a well defined comment
in their requirements.txt. This allows us to easily find the list of
project to receive neutron-lib consumption patches [2] by searching for
the string.

In addition, projects opting-in for these patches are also attesting
they will stay up to date with TC and infra initiatives to ensure
consumption patches can flow freely.

This patch adds the "neutron-lib-current" string to requirements.txt
opting in for neutron-lib consumption patches.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/neutron-stein-ptg
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron-lib/latest/contributor/contributing.html#phase-4-consume

Change-Id: I7ece3a500fc488a8c8365036734be2dc16ce716c
'}]
commit_message:
opt in for neutron-lib consumption patches

As part of the Denver PTG [1] we decided networking related projects
that are "current" and want to receive neutron-lib consumption patches
on an on-going basis should indicate such with a well defined comment
in their requirements.txt. This allows us to easily find the list of
project to receive neutron-lib consumption patches [2] by searching for
the string.

In addition, projects opting-in for these patches are also attesting
they will stay up to date with TC and infra initiatives to ensure
consumption patches can flow freely.

This patch adds the "neutron-lib-current" string to requirements.txt
opting in for neutron-lib consumption patches.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/neutron-stein-ptg
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron-lib/latest/contributor/contributing.html#phase-4-consume

Change-Id: I7ece3a500fc488a8c8365036734be2dc16ce716c

commit_message:
Restore timeout_scaling_factor

In a previous refactor, we lost the part where we actually multiple
TIMEOUT_SCALING_FACTOR to the timeout. Whoops.

Also, turn off keepalive in the underlying session. For devstack
functional tests, we're seeing a lot of "Resetting dropped connection"
so I'm thinking we should just disable that.

Also, increase the individual test timeout, and bump the scaling factor
on trunk tests, which always seem to be timing out.

Change-Id: Ie5b3eb319fed10cabfb2e818f3fcfd52b6fd7b14

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-21 16:18:13.000000000', 'message': 'VMware: Improve scalability of querying volumes

Currently we query volumes in vCenter by name which is not scalable.
Commit 6b9464e91840f6e006f537dcd3c0f656ae90a179 sets the backend
volume ID to Cinder volume ID so that we can use vCenter SearchIndex
API to query backend volumes by Cinder volume ID.

This patch uses SearchIndex API to improve scalability. But this type
of querying will not work for legacy volumes whose vCenter ID is not
set to Cinder volume ID. To handle those volumes, we build a cache to
map their names to vCenter references during driver setup.

Closes-bug: #1600754
Change-Id: I6b49c2590d0bd3946fa03dbac08ab4f778007111
(cherry picked from commit 46b8da35d79121df34ec9befd353c8c428be846b)
'}]
commit_message:
VMware: Improve scalability of querying volumes

Currently we query volumes in vCenter by name which is not scalable.
Commit 6b9464e91840f6e006f537dcd3c0f656ae90a179 sets the backend
volume ID to Cinder volume ID so that we can use vCenter SearchIndex
API to query backend volumes by Cinder volume ID.

This patch uses SearchIndex API to improve scalability. But this type
of querying will not work for legacy volumes whose vCenter ID is not
set to Cinder volume ID. To handle those volumes, we build a cache to
map their names to vCenter references during driver setup.

Closes-bug: #1600754
Change-Id: I6b49c2590d0bd3946fa03dbac08ab4f778007111
(cherry picked from commit 46b8da35d79121df34ec9befd353c8c428be846b)

commit_message:
placement: Always reset conf.CONF when starting the wsgi app

This ensures that options loaded during any prior run of the application
are dropped before being added again during init_application.

Change-Id: I41b5c7990d4d62a3a397f1686261f3fb7dc1a0be
Closes-bug: #1784155

commit_message:
tasks: lxc_install_zypper: Use the 'state' option for external repos

The state of the Containers repository depends on the Leap version
that's being used. Before this patch, we did not override the default
value of the 'state' option so the repository was always added. However,
we don't need to use this repo for Leap 15 so we need to use the 'state'
value from the distro variables.

Change-Id: Ia41ffaa21fede271263c1757de949e65f6f30a67

commit_message:
doc: add known limitation about attaching SR-IOV ports

Nova does not currently support attaching SR-IOV ports to
existing instances, you can only create a server with an
SR-IOV port at this time. This adds an item about that
limitation to the SR-IOV admin docs.

Change-Id: I0a954de724384a81cb45446da20fa6b17d4bd63a
Related-Bug: #1708433

commit_message:
Set max microversion 2.43 for add_fixed_ip

add_fixed_ip is deprecated from microversion 2.44, so this is
to set microversion 2.43 for add_fixed_ip.

https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#add-associate-fixed-ip-addfixedip-action-deprecated

partially-implements: blueprint clear-deprecated-api

Change-Id: I78b19b06fecc0191958e9ff0e8b203cd5ab9a8a4

commit_message:
VMware: ensure that live migration attaches to correct interface

Ensure that the live migration attaches to the correct neutron
port group or opaque network.

When we do the live migration we make sure that the correct
network backings are used.

Change-Id: I1d2965b436c896e5a8dacbce26f74055faa89128

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-26 01:44:39.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for RHSM Pools

Support rhsm_pool_ids parameter (it was documented but not used).
This parameter helps to specify the subscription pool IDs to consume.

A pool ID may be specified as a string - just the pool ID
(ex. 0123456789abcdef0123456789abcdef), or as a dict with the pool ID as the
key, and a quantity as the value (ex. 0123456789abcdef0123456789abcdef: 2).
If the quantity is provided, it is used to consume multiple entitlements from
a pool (the pool must support this).

Change-Id: I5658fa97e32193045c9da29126e824a884054e60
'}]
commit_message:
Add support for RHSM Pools

Support rhsm_pool_ids parameter (it was documented but not used).
This parameter helps to specify the subscription pool IDs to consume.

A pool ID may be specified as a string - just the pool ID
(ex. 0123456789abcdef0123456789abcdef), or as a dict with the pool ID as the
key, and a quantity as the value (ex. 0123456789abcdef0123456789abcdef: 2).
If the quantity is provided, it is used to consume multiple entitlements from
a pool (the pool must support this).

Change-Id: I5658fa97e32193045c9da29126e824a884054e60

The direction makes sense. We need some test coverage but then it is good to go'}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-08-15 14:42:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

The openstack/nova-powervm virt driver does support attaching SR-IOV ports today, and this would break that. Instead of a hard fast-fail, let's make this capability-based so that the PowerVM driver can continue to support it."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-08-15 14:45:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

+1 to what Matthew says.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-08-16 01:39:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> openstack/nova-powervm virt driver

Umm, sorry but I don't really care if an out of tree driver supports something. I'm not planning on adding capabilities flags to support out of tree features."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-08-16 05:20:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2018-08-16 06:13:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only zvm: recheck in the comment. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-22813 : SUCCESS in 52m 57s'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-08-16 07:35:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Build succeeded.

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/591898/2 : SUCCESS in 2h 14m 18s'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-08-16 12:14:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

> Umm, sorry but I don't really care if an out of tree driver supports something. I'm not planning on adding capabilities flags to support out of tree features.

To me it's less about OOT driver support and more about an API operation changing its behavior without a microversion. Okay if it used to 500, but that was clearly only the case for some drivers."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-08-16 20:00:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> > Umm, sorry but I don't really care if an out of tree driver
 > supports something. I'm not planning on adding capabilities flags
 > to support out of tree features.
 > 
 > To me it's less about OOT driver support and more about an API
 > operation changing its behavior without a microversion. Okay if it
 > used to 500, but that was clearly only the case for some drivers.

IMO, this used to work for an OOT driver "by accident." Attaching SRIOV ports to existing instances hasn't been supported (there have been specs propose to add it) and the current behavior we have now, for in-tree drivers, is akin to a 500 in my opinion -- a KeyError once the path gets to nova-compute. Since we know we don't support it, why should we continue returning a success status code from the API only to have it fail in nova-compute?'}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-08-16 20:32:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

It doesn't work by accident for nova-powervm. That was very intentional. And that driver is being ported in-tree, so nova will soon have an in-tree driver supporting SR-IOV attachment.

I'm not suggesting that we live with bug 1708433 as-is. If we add a virt driver capability we can fail more nicely if/when a driver doesn't support SR-IOV attachment while still allowing drivers to support SR-IOV attachment."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-08-16 20:47:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> It doesn't work by accident for nova-powervm. That was very
 > intentional. And that driver is being ported in-tree, so nova will
 > soon have an in-tree driver supporting SR-IOV attachment.
 > 
 > I'm not suggesting that we live with bug 1708433 as-is. If we add a
 > virt driver capability we can fail more nicely if/when a driver
 > doesn't support SR-IOV attachment while still allowing drivers to
 > support SR-IOV attachment.

When I say "by accident," I mean that nova does not support hot-plugging of SRIOV ports and there's a loophole where the request gets to nova-compute before it fails/doesn't work for any in-tree driver, that the OOT has been using. That is my understanding of the situation.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-08-17 06:56:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Look, if the powervm driver team wants to support this, they can work on the spec to add the support upstream in-tree, which might include adding a microversion to indicate when it's supported, since arguably that's needed for interoperability. It's more than a driver capability, it's a capability of the cloud (and potentially a policy rule is needed if a cloud is using virt drivers or networking backends that don't support it so they can disable via policy). Attempting to block this in-tree fail-fast change because of an out of tree driver relying on it is completely inappropriate IMO."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-08-17 06:58:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> I'm not suggesting that we live with bug 1708433 as-is. If we add a
virt driver capability we can fail more nicely if/when a driver
doesn't support SR-IOV attachment while still allowing drivers to
support SR-IOV attachment.

So if StarlingX has a virt driver that supports specifying the CPU model in the flavor, or live resize, or specifying the L3 cache, do we add a capability to support that out of tree driver even though *nothing* in tree supports it? No way."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-08-17 15:29:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Attempting to block this in-tree fail-fast change because of an out of tree driver relying on it is completely inappropriate IMO.

-1 is by definition not blocking, and its use by two contributors and consumers of nova to signal "we have a problem with this: it will have a negative impact on the folks who enable our contribution" is completely appropriate. Can we lose the invective and discuss the issue on its merits please?

It seems like Matthew's suggestion would be an easy-to-implement compromise to bridge the gap until formal in-tree support is ironed out. And I'm sure he would be happy to work the code.

If that's deemed a nonstarter by the core team (from which I'm excluding myself for purposes of this patch, btw, due to obvious conflict of interest), so be it. In that case, this patch should at least include a doc update in [1] to state explicitly that live attach is not supported. (In other news, that doc has some malformed links that ought to be fixed.) It would also be nice to see a patch for the corresponding neutron doc [2], which already has a "Known Limitations" section, but this ain't in it.

And, since we know this breaks at least one OOT driver, a courtesy ML email would be neighborly. I'd be willing to compose that if you'd like.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/pci-passthrough.html
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/admin/config-sriov'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-08-18 22:36:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

Adding some type of capability flag for this in-tree for something that's not supported by anything in-tree is a non-starter for me. Nova doesn't support out of tree drivers:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/contributor/policies.html#out-of-tree-support

If it helps to update the nova/neutron SRIOV docs to explicitly state that hot plugging SRIOV ports is not currently supported, I'll do that, and send something to the ML about it sure."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-08-21 15:42:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-08-21 15:50:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

I'm also reluctant to add a capability for an out-of-tree driver. The capability feature would be a good add but only once said driver is in tree. However, I'm sticking with +1 in case there is further discussion to happen."}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-08-21 16:05:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

I'll yield. I'm glad to see the docs updated along with this. Thanks, Matt."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-08-21 16:06:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thanks for the doc adds and the ML post Matt ([1] fmr).

Passive-aggressive +1.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-August/133600.html'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-08-21 16:06:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-08-21 18:05:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Build succeeded.

commit_message:
Explicitly fail if trying to attach SR-IOV port

Attaching SR-IOV ports to existing instances is not supported
since the compute service does not perform any kind of PCI
device allocation, so we should fail fast with a clear error
if attempted. Note that the compute RPC API "attach_interface"
method is an RPC call from nova-api to nova-compute so the error
raised here will result in a 400 response to the user.

Blueprint sriov-interface-attach-detach would need to be
implemented to support this use case, and could arguably involve
a microversion to indicate when the feature was made available.

A related neutron docs patch https://review.openstack.org/594325
is posted for mentioning the limitation with SR-IOV port attach
as well.

Change-Id: Ibbf2bd3cdd45bcd61eebff883c30ded525b2495d
Closes-Bug: #1708433

commit_message:
nova-status - don't count deleted compute_nodes

When counting rows in the compute_nodes table to compare against
resource records, those which have been marked as deleted should
not be counted, otherwise the result is artificially high.

Change-Id: Ia3fbb9c46c15826fc363286ce48984f59cbe1e62
Closes-Bug: #1757207
(cherry picked from commit 3e902313e9c3117e76d6adf88a2f104bc229374c)

Trim away the cover and py35 jobs

Also, we don't really care about the cover jobs.

subject: Remove the task manager
messages: [{'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-09-25 12:19:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3099, 'date': '2018-09-26 14:01:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-25 12:19:14.000000000', 'message': 'Remove the task manager

The underlying openstacksdk library is shifting how task manager works,
so stop trying to send it a task manager. This is a feature basically in
place just for nodepool which is being expanded to be more usable by
everyone. The likelihood that anyone other than nodepool is using it is
... very low.

Change-Id: I04be3937589a805a5f9686c91a78933eebcfa022
'}]
commit_message:
Remove the task manager

The underlying openstacksdk library is shifting how task manager works,
so stop trying to send it a task manager. This is a feature basically in
place just for nodepool which is being expanded to be more usable by
everyone. The likelihood that anyone other than nodepool is using it is
... very low.

Change-Id: I04be3937589a805a5f9686c91a78933eebcfa022

waiting for status changes in the cells v1 job, so blacklist it.
Cells v1 is deprecated and should be gone soon anyway, so we don't
need to waste time hitting stuff like this.

commit_message:
Skip ServerActionsTestJSON.test_rebuild_server for cells v1 job

This is another occurrence of a rebuild test randomly timing out
waiting for status changes in the cells v1 job, so blacklist it.
Cells v1 is deprecated and should be gone soon anyway, so we don't
need to waste time hitting stuff like this.

Change-Id: Icb1d33c6e602467e21efe4838cb6edbadab14834
Related-Bug: #1709985
(cherry picked from commit 927b6ccced40a189ce9ee6b1486b54599b74c444)

[{'created': '2018-09-24 18:46:53.000000000', 'message': "add a 'releasefix' mode for re-tagging existing releases

When we have a lot of release jobs fail, it is easier to just
re-release things than to try to fix the problems one at a time. This
change makes it easier to prepare the relevant changes.

Change-Id: I0e3dca1e42278374b03ad6e83c48aa98a8f2e2c4
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
"}]
commit_message:
add a 'releasefix' mode for re-tagging existing releases

When we have a lot of release jobs fail, it is easier to just
re-release things than to try to fix the problems one at a time. This
change makes it easier to prepare the relevant changes.

Change-Id: I0e3dca1e42278374b03ad6e83c48aa98a8f2e2c4
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

[{'created': '2018-09-13 09:16:01.000000000', 'message': 'Fix bug of retyping volume for rbd driver

If the volume is already in the pool, renaming causes exception.
The Scene is that the same pool is seti into two backends with
different volume_backend_name. Then create two volume types with
different volume_backend_name which was defined in cinder.conf.
Create a volume by one volume type, then try to retype it to another
volume type. It failed because of ImageExists.

commit_message:
Fix bug of renaming volume with same name

If the volume is already in the pool, renaming causes exception.
It failed because of ImageExists.

Change-Id: I81951da141ed7948e48b92da718b3a0e9c12e859
Closes-Bug: #1792339

looks like a timing error in the tests'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-09-25 19:10:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

oic, I didn't test this case because I use conf.d and it's pretty inconvenient for me to functionally move all my proxy config into a flat file :\

It's so akward how the kmip client takes a file path instead of a dict, and i don't really understand why we even bother to support the "option" of configuring it in the filter section!?  I'm not sure it matters how much this works, doesn't seem to break the more reasonable deployment pattern tho.  *shurg*'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2018-09-26 06:56:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Testing in my kmip enabled SAIO. failed when defined in proxy.conf on master but works which this patch. Nice work Tim.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-24 23:55:07.000000000', 'message': 'Allow kmip_keymaster to be configured in proxy-server.conf

... and in particular, in the filter:kmip_keymaster section. We thought
we'd done that before, but we didn't: __name__ is *just* the filter
name, and doesn't include the "filter:" prefix for the section.

Change-Id: Iede1d7450e94ba05d2610030e975f566275da88b
'}]
commit_message:
Allow kmip_keymaster to be configured in proxy-server.conf

... and in particular, in the filter:kmip_keymaster section. We thought
we'd done that before, but we didn't: __name__ is *just* the filter
name, and doesn't include the "filter:" prefix for the section.

Change-Id: Iede1d7450e94ba05d2610030e975f566275da88b

commit_message:
Clean up comment about 404s leaking out during COPYs

Apparently that isn't a thing we have to worry about any more? Probably
got fixed when we pulled COPY out to middleware.

Add some tests where we definitely expect 403s across the board, too.

Change-Id: Idb5c0b25969b839cc71c487208447bdd6817c2cf

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-21 09:57:37.000000000', 'message': "Parse dhcp leases file in a more robust way

It turns out that in environments with a big number of VMs, sometimes
the neutron dhcp agent fails to read the dhcp lease file because some
lines with the ipv4/ipv6 entries don't have enough fields and causes the
dhcp agent to fail.

When this happens the agent calls sync_state to
fully resync the agent state, that causes a serious performance problems
in scale environments.

We need to be more robust reading the file to handle these exceptions.

Co-authored-by: stephen-ma
Partial-Bug: #1788556

Change-Id: Ia681a5e929df5bf8c97ae9445876c306c34061b5
(cherry picked from commit 8a3ff8a19ec39630d24b71cec86740b6b9f16bbe)
"}, {'created': '2018-09-21 17:03:32.000000000', 'message': "Parse dhcp leases file in a more robust way

It turns out that in environments with a big number of VMs, sometimes
the neutron dhcp agent fails to read the dhcp lease file because some
lines with the ipv4/ipv6 entries don't have enough fields and causes the
dhcp agent to fail.

When this happens the agent calls sync_state to
fully resync the agent state, that causes a serious performance problems
in scale environments.

We need to be more robust reading the file to handle these exceptions.

Co-authored-by: stephen-ma
Partial-Bug: #1788556

Change-Id: Ia681a5e929df5bf8c97ae9445876c306c34061b5
(cherry picked from commit 8a3ff8a19ec39630d24b71cec86740b6b9f16bbe)
"}]
commit_message:
Parse dhcp leases file in a more robust way

It turns out that in environments with a big number of VMs, sometimes
the neutron dhcp agent fails to read the dhcp lease file because some
lines with the ipv4/ipv6 entries don't have enough fields and causes the
dhcp agent to fail.

When this happens the agent calls sync_state to
fully resync the agent state, that causes a serious performance problems
in scale environments.

We need to be more robust reading the file to handle these exceptions.

Co-authored-by: stephen-ma
Partial-Bug: #1788556

Change-Id: Ia681a5e929df5bf8c97ae9445876c306c34061b5
(cherry picked from commit 8a3ff8a19ec39630d24b71cec86740b6b9f16bbe)

commit_message:
Refactor GetTransportSadPathTestCase

GetTransportSadPathTestCase did an awful lot of mocking for things that
were no longer called. Since we only have one callable now, make use of
self.assertRaises.

Change-Id: Ie93ff74de84ff4d6cc75a3c89dd9a03fdcba5d35

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-14 16:57:40.000000000', 'message': 'Consumer gen: remove_provider_from_instance_allocation

This patch changes the scheduler report client
remove_provider_from_instance_allocation function to retry the whole
function if it receives 409 from placement that indicates a consumer
generation conflict. If we run out of retries then the function returns
False indicating an unsuccessful allocation removal.

There are plenty of places in nova calling
remove_provider_from_instance_allocation:
* dropping allocation on the destination of a live migrate if pre check
  fails
* compute host startup deletes allocation of an instance that was
  successfully evacuated from the host while it was down
* rebuild fails on the destination of an evacuation and therefore
  the allocation on the destination is deleted
* pre resize fails therefore allocation on the destination is deleted

This patch does not change the external behavior of
remove_provider_from_instance_allocation as it still returns False in
caes of failure. Therefore this patch does not introduce new functional
test for the above cases but rely on the exiting coverage. However based
on the other patches in this series the error handling in these cases
suspected to be imperfect.

TODO:
* make the unit test pass

Change-Id: I328a18a723d0f593eea491f788a6e256d6e0c127

commit_message:
Consumer gen: remove_provider_from_instance_allocation

This patch changes the scheduler report client
remove_provider_from_instance_allocation function to use placement API
microversion 1.28 that includes consumer generation handling. If
placement returns 409 conflict remove_provider_from_instance_allocation
returns False in the same way as in case of other non 204 results.

There are plenty of places in nova calling
remove_provider_from_instance_allocation:
* dropping allocation on the destination of a live migrate if pre check
  fails
* compute host startup deletes allocation of an instance that was
  successfully evacuated from the host while it was down
* rebuild fails on the destination of an evacuation and therefore
  the allocation on the destination is deleted
* pre resize fails therefore allocation on the destination is deleted

This patch does not change the external behavior of
remove_provider_from_instance_allocation as it still returns False in
caes of failure. Therefore this patch does not introduce new functional
test for the above cases but rely on the existing coverage. However based
on the other patches in this series the error handling in these cases
is suspected to be imperfect.

Blueprint: use-nested-allocation-candidates
Change-Id: I328a18a723d0f593eea491f788a6e256d6e0c127
