(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2018-09-25 16:45:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 19316, 'date': '2018-09-25 16:46:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-09-25 16:51:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-24 15:55:51.000000000', 'message': 'Downgrade Logstash for Monasca

Logstash was added to Kolla as part of the effort to deploy Monasca.

Monasca uses Kafka messaging version 0.9 which is not supported by
Logstash 5.x with the default Kafka input/output plugins. An attempt
to downgrade the plugins to the 4.x series which should be compatible
with messaging version 0.9 and Logstash 5.x failed. Therefore, until
Monasca is upgraded (work is ongoing) this patch downgrades
Logstash to 2.4.1.

Although it would have been simpler to perform the downgrade by
blacklisting the Logstash 5.x package which is provided as part of the
official ELK repo and installing the official repo for Logstash 2.4.1,
Ubuntu 18.04 no longer accepts SHA1 hashes (for good reason) and will
not install Logstash 2.4.1 from this repo (fails with GPG error).
This approach does however work for Centos, but for consistency it
was not used.

This change therefore modifies the Logstash dockerfile, and directly
downloads and installs the Logstash 2.4.1 package. It should be
reverted as soon as Monasca is upgraded.

Partially-Implements: blueprint monasca-containers
Change-Id: I58fba9ceded4b3a198136df084c7d37365ab47a8
'}]
commit_message:
Downgrade Logstash for Monasca

Logstash was added to Kolla as part of the effort to deploy Monasca.

Monasca uses Kafka messaging version 0.9 which is not supported by
Logstash 5.x with the default Kafka input/output plugins. An attempt
to downgrade the plugins to the 4.x series which should be compatible
with messaging version 0.9 and Logstash 5.x failed. Therefore, until
Monasca is upgraded (work is ongoing) this patch downgrades
Logstash to 2.4.1.

Although it would have been simpler to perform the downgrade by
blacklisting the Logstash 5.x package which is provided as part of the
official ELK repo and installing the official repo for Logstash 2.4.1,
Ubuntu 18.04 no longer accepts SHA1 hashes (for good reason) and will
not install Logstash 2.4.1 from this repo (fails with GPG error).
This approach does however work for Centos, but for consistency it
was not used.

This change therefore modifies the Logstash dockerfile, and directly
downloads and installs the Logstash 2.4.1 package. It should be
reverted as soon as Monasca is upgraded.

Partially-Implements: blueprint monasca-containers
Change-Id: I58fba9ceded4b3a198136df084c7d37365ab47a8

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-24 11:06:08.000000000', 'message': 'Disable debug logs for image builds

Logs emitted when building via the tox environments can exceed the
maximum length supported by subunit [1], causing the following message:

Length too long: <length>

This change disables debug logging in these tox environments to reduce
the length of the output.

[1]
https://github.com/testing-cabal/subunit/blob/8cdd703980c314dddf95cc0556f67bc80358ddcd/python/subunit/v2.py#L208

Change-Id: Icb5793a8ea58edafe2f3a249eb1da7d4ae2e395f
'}]
commit_message:
Disable debug logs for image builds

Logs emitted when building via the tox environments can exceed the
maximum length supported by subunit [1], causing the following message:

Length too long: <length>

This change disables debug logging in these tox environments to reduce
the length of the output.

[1]
https://github.com/testing-cabal/subunit/blob/8cdd703980c314dddf95cc0556f67bc80358ddcd/python/subunit/v2.py#L208

Change-Id: Icb5793a8ea58edafe2f3a249eb1da7d4ae2e395f

commit_message:
Provide support for freezer dev mode in kolla

Add a possibility to mount sources as volumes to containers,
in "more than documentation" way. That will let us to use kolla
as a replacement for devstack.

Partially implements: blueprint mount-sources
Co-Authored-By: wu.chunyang <wu.chunyang@99cloud.net>

Change-Id: Ia3112a0d297ac777e1f25d3ddecced7746ca6418

commit_message:
Revert the patch set "Apply Swift rolling upgrade"

Due to there is no way to execute swift graceful shutdown commands
from swift-bootstrap container to swift service containers, so
we need to revert the patch set at [1].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/560248/

Change-Id: I3363895347c535054584d63e22284c211ca38ad6

which have zero-padding disabled, to contain previous data. This
change prevents these volumes from being created by default. A

This is a squash of the four commits that led to the final state in

commit_message:
ScaleIO: Prevent usage of unsafe volumes

It is possible for volumes, created from storage pools
which have zero-padding disabled, to contain previous data. This
change prevents these volumes from being created by default. A
user can override this behavior by acknowleding the possibility
with a configuration option.

This is a squash of the four commits that led to the final state in
rocky to not allow the creation of any type of non-zero-padded volumes
to be created. This adds a config option that defaults to the safe
behavior. It is backporting a new config option, and a change in default
behavior, but it should be acceptable in this case so that the security
vulnerability can be addressed.

Closes-Bug: #1784871

Change-Id: I62f8f48b1624fc9abb7427bd4ca51f7873d35b96
Closes-bug: #1699573
(cherry picked from commit f0cef07bef5ea8ed29179ee3774df5f4a634ba86)
(cherry picked from commit 6309c097e653c5f8b40e0602950d0ef54a9efb37)

commit_message:
Remove broken uptime tests during upgrade

The uptime tests during upgrades have not been
working for some time, and we really need a better
way to implement them anyway.

To at least allow upgrade tests to work without
their interference, we remove the scripts and
implementation.

Change-Id: I33f7994a50ba5fcea7fca171dfca6b4d32011900

commit_message:
Fix location region field in docs

The docs said a location object had a 'region' field, however the field
name is 'region_name'.

https://github.com/openstack/openstacksdk/blob/4efbf96192805d336f3b013f37bb933b21dab2cc/openstack/cloud/openstackcloud.py#L716

Story: #2003871
Task: #26709

Change-Id: I0271a5a738e998032d67c2c5c6152c8583f41bd7

commit_message:
Use no-op drivers for Octavia in gate

Continue to test Heat's interaction with the Octavia API without relying on
Octavia's interaction with Nova, Neutron &c. which is known to be unstable.

Change-Id: I8765aceee09ada3086abc704b7f73ce240e21847

[{'created': '2018-08-26 04:09:05.000000000', 'message': 'Pass nova_ceph_client_uuid down to the ceph_client role

Ansible does not automatically import the variables of the parent
role when doing an include_role, therefore, the ceph_client role
fails to find the proper nova_ceph_client_uuid when being included.

This explicitly adds it and makes sure that it is passed down to
the role.

Change-Id: Id6c05d5a4262db7f416dde5e10d7001b537eb56d
(cherry picked from commit af5751d70e7c5caa9c978deaf99dc95a9cbdee04)
'}]
commit_message:
Pass nova_ceph_client_uuid down to the ceph_client role

Ansible does not automatically import the variables of the parent
role when doing an include_role, therefore, the ceph_client role
fails to find the proper nova_ceph_client_uuid when being included.

This explicitly adds it and makes sure that it is passed down to
the role.

Change-Id: Id6c05d5a4262db7f416dde5e10d7001b537eb56d
(cherry picked from commit af5751d70e7c5caa9c978deaf99dc95a9cbdee04)

[{'created': '2018-09-25 16:29:09.000000000', 'message': 'Glean config on OVH nodes

Instruct glean via metadata properties to ignore the config drive
network_data.json interface data on OVH and instead fall back to DHCP.
This is necessary because post upgrade OVH config drive
network_data.json provides inaccurate network configuration details and
DHCP is actually what is needed there for working l2 networking.

Change-Id: I51f16d34a96ee8d964e8b540ce5113a662a56f6d
'}]
commit_message:
Glean config on OVH nodes

Instruct glean via metadata properties to ignore the config drive
network_data.json interface data on OVH and instead fall back to DHCP.
This is necessary because post upgrade OVH config drive
network_data.json provides inaccurate network configuration details and
DHCP is actually what is needed there for working l2 networking.

Change-Id: I51f16d34a96ee8d964e8b540ce5113a662a56f6d

[{'created': '2018-08-22 16:32:23.000000000', 'message': "Add serial numbers for local disks

It is possible to assign a serial number to virtual hard disks which
can be queried by the guest operating system. We currently do this for
attached volumes, but we don't do it for local disks: local root
disks, ephemerals, or swap disks.

Previously-approved: Queens Rocky
Blueprint: local-disk-serial-numbers

Change-Id: I7787fb3873a49082d7ca4eb5b90ec07af7370184
"}]
commit_message:
Add serial numbers for local disks

It is possible to assign a serial number to virtual hard disks which
can be queried by the guest operating system. We currently do this for
attached volumes, but we don't do it for local disks: local root
disks, ephemerals, or swap disks.

Previously-approved: Queens Rocky
Blueprint: local-disk-serial-numbers

Change-Id: I7787fb3873a49082d7ca4eb5b90ec07af7370184

commit_message:
Dump zuul variables to file

we need to pass some zuul variables to the inner ansible calls. We dump
the zuul variables subtree to a file, then we add it as extra-vars to
the ansible calls.

Change-Id: I8d7c877b64cf22c00b1ad538f25ad4ff87574a8a

(1 comment)

the handling looks sane, but I've got a question within about implicit return None v return False

Also we need to be clear that this handling of deleting allocations is only right when we are completely sure that a consumer generation conflict is not a problem and simply ignoring it and retrying it is okay.

We need to be careful about that because if all we ever do is retry (and expect it to eventually work), then why have generations at all? Presumably later in the stack there will be different handling."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-08-16 08:50:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

(1 comment)

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > the handling looks sane, but I've got a question within about
 > implicit return None v return False
 > 
 > Also we need to be clear that this handling of deleting allocations
 > is only right when we are completely sure that a consumer
 > generation conflict is not a problem and simply ignoring it and
 > retrying it is okay.
 > 
 > We need to be careful about that because if all we ever do is retry
 > (and expect it to eventually work), then why have generations at
 > all? Presumably later in the stack there will be different
 > handling.

I totally agree with your problem statement. Consumer generation is introduced to detect conflict, if we just blindly retry then this safety feature worth nothing. I see two options:
A) blindly retry couple of times. When we run out of retries then fail and let the user retry
B) do not retry but fail right away and let the end user retry

I think this is the time I need to write this up on the ML to spark some discussion."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-08-16 11:45:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Starting the discussion on the ML http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-August/133374.html'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-08-20 13:43:51.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to consumer_gen'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-08-31 09:06:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-08-31 09:07:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

refactored based on the ML discussion http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-August/133374.html'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-09-12 22:40:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-09-15 17:57:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

I don't think this is a significant improvement, as the race still exists where the "mysterious third party" makes a change before we get into the report client method.

If we're not maintaining a cache of allocations/consumers (we're not - and let's keep it that way), it doesn't do us much good to make this particular switchover. If we're getting into this method, we're deleting the instance, and so we just want to delete the allocations. I.e. we can/should just keep using the DELETE route.

I may have more to say about this once I've seen the rest of the series.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-09-17 09:01:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-09-17 11:08:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

See PS3'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-09-19 14:18:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

Missing the consumer_generation in the request payload for PUT /allocations/{consumer_uuid} :)'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-09-21 08:45:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(4 comments)

> (3 comments)
 > 
 > I don't think this is a significant improvement, as the race still
 > exists where the "mysterious third party" makes a change before we
 > get into the report client method.

What this patch and the next couple of patches in the series do is that they make such conflict visible for the outside word and therefore make it possible to know about cases when such conflict happens in the field as we expect that it cannot happen with the current code base of OpenStack.

 > 
 > If we're not maintaining a cache of allocations/consumers (we're
 > not - and let's keep it that way), it doesn't do us much good to
 > make this particular switchover. If we're getting into this method,
 > we're deleting the instance, and so we just want to delete the
 > allocations. I.e. we can/should just keep using the DELETE route.

Yeah, if we agree that nova owns the allocation held by the instance_uuid as consumer then sure nova can delete it without considering others as others are forbidden to touch such allocation. I think the idea of consumer generation support in placement was born because we are hesitant to say that others cannot touch nova's allocations.

 > 
 > I may have more to say about this once I've seen the rest of the
 > series.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-09-21 12:43:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-09-21 12:53:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

(6 comments)

Thank for the review I've fixed the issues."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-09-21 13:13:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Build succeeded.

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/591597/5 : SUCCESS in 2h 36m 16s'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-21 15:27:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-21 15:29:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-09-21 15:39:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> What this patch and the next couple of patches in the series do is that they make such conflict visible for the outside word and therefore make it possible to know about cases when such conflict happens in the field

This patch does not make a conflict visible unless it happens to occur in the teeny window *within* the method itself. IMO introducing this code could make one *think* we're doing so, which is bad. Because the vast, vast majority of cases where such conflicts occur (allocation gets mucked with between when the instance is created and when the deletion process begins) will go completely unnoticed.

I'm not going to block this if Matt and Jay are in favor, but I still think this is a step backwards."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-09-21 15:40:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

Ah, hell, I'm going to downvote until the three of you ack that you at least understand my issue."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-09-24 09:24:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> > What this patch and the next couple of patches in the series do
 > is that they make such conflict visible for the outside word and
 > therefore make it possible to know about cases when such conflict
 > happens in the field
 > 
 > This patch does not make a conflict visible unless it happens to
 > occur in the teeny window *within* the method itself. IMO
 > introducing this code could make one *think* we're doing so, which
 > is bad. Because the vast, vast majority of cases where such
 > conflicts occur (allocation gets mucked with between when the
 > instance is created and when the deletion process begins) will go
 > completely unnoticed.
 > 
 > I'm not going to block this if Matt and Jay are in favor, but I
 > still think this is a step backwards.

In this patch series most of the patches do the same thing just for different use cases:
1) End user triggers a lifecycle operation on the a server
2) Nova figures out that the allocation of that server needs to be changed
3) Nova GETs the current allocation from placement, and PUTs back the new allocation.
4) If between the GET and PUT the allocation is changed in placement then Nova fails.

Delete allocation is special in placement as it still can be done without considering the consumer generation but the rest of the allocation manipulation cannot ignore the generation (when version > 1.28) and therefore needs to be prepared to handle consumer generation conflict. While technically it is possible to ignore the generation during delete this would make the allocation handling asymmetric in nova and I don't like that at all.

What do you suggest what shall these code patches do if the conflict happens within the short time window?
a) fail the lifecycle operation (this is what this series is aiming for)
b) retry couple of times but eventually fail (I think we agreed not to do that in the mailthread)
c) cheat a bit and user version <1.28 for every operation except where it is explicitly needs bigger like claim during scheduling and reshape."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-09-24 16:02:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-09-24 16:04:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

(6 comments)

I've fixed the comments, added an extra test for local delete returning 409 and noted that this patch only detect a small portion of possible parallel allocation modifications."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-09-24 16:18:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-09-24 16:18:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

...and rebased to resolve the conflict'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2018-09-24 17:09:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

[{'created': '2018-08-14 09:35:25.000000000', 'message': 'Consumer gen support for delete instance allocations

The placement API version 1.28 introduced consumer generation as a way
to make updating allocation safe even if it is done from multiple
places.

This patch changes delete_allocation_for_instance to use PUT
/allocations instead of DELETE /allocations to benefit from the consumer
generation handling.

In this patch the report client will GET the current allocation of the
instance including the consumer generation and then try to PUT an empty
allocation with that generation. If this fails due to a consumer
generation conflict, meaning something modified the allocation of the
instance in between GET and PUT then the report client will retry the
whole operation. After 3 failed retry the report client will raise
AllocationDeleteFailed.

TODO:
* As the functional test shows when AllocationDeleteFailed raised the
  instance is marked deleted and the instance allocation is leaked. We
  need to put the instance into ERROR state instead to let the user
  retry the delete later.
* make the unit test pass

Change-Id: I77f34788dd7ab8fdf60d668a4f76452e03cf9888
'}, {'created': '2018-08-31 09:06:02.000000000', 'message': 'Consumer gen support for delete instance allocations

to make updating allocation safe even if it is done from multiple

allocation with that generation. If this fails due to a consumer
generation conflict, meaning something modified the allocation of the
instance in between GET and PUT then the report client will raise
AllocationDeleteFailed exception. This will cause that the instance
goes to ERROR state.

To be able to put the instance state to ERROR the instance.destroy()
call is moved to the end to of the deletion call path. To keep the
instance.delete.end notification behavior consistent with this move
(e.g. deleted_at field is filled) the notification sending needed to
be moved too.

Change-Id: I77f34788dd7ab8fdf60d668a4f76452e03cf9888

commit_message:
Consumer gen support for delete instance allocations

The placement API version 1.28 introduced consumer generation as a way
to make updating allocation safe even if it is done from multiple
places.

This patch changes delete_allocation_for_instance to use PUT
/allocations instead of DELETE /allocations to benefit from the consumer
generation handling.

In this patch the report client will GET the current allocation of the
instance including the consumer generation and then try to PUT an empty
allocation with that generation. If this fails due to a consumer
generation conflict, meaning something modified the allocation of the
instance in between GET and PUT then the report client will raise
AllocationDeleteFailed exception. This will cause that the instance
goes to ERROR state.

This patch only detects a small portion of possible cases when
allocation is modified outside of the delete code path. The rest can
only be detected if nova would cache at least the consumer generation
of the instance.

To be able to put the instance state to ERROR the instance.destroy()
call is moved to the end to of the deletion call path. To keep the
instance.delete.end notification behavior consistent with this move
(e.g. deleted_at field is filled) the notification sending needed to
be moved too.

Blueprint: use-nested-allocation-candidates
Change-Id: I77f34788dd7ab8fdf60d668a4f76452e03cf9888

messages: [{'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-09-20 10:38:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-09-25 16:25:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-20 10:38:37.000000000', 'message': "MNAIO: Disable metering services by default

The telemetry stack is not maintained well within the OSA community
as it's rarely used by the maintainers. As such, we rather disable
it by default. It's easy enough to opt in if it's required.

Change-Id: I498bad8549e926d48164069896b9116c3d5a33da
"}]
commit_message:
MNAIO: Disable metering services by default

The telemetry stack is not maintained well within the OSA community
as it's rarely used by the maintainers. As such, we rather disable
it by default. It's easy enough to opt in if it's required.

Change-Id: I498bad8549e926d48164069896b9116c3d5a33da

The DNS_NAMESERVER environment variable in the service
setup script does not have a default. We ensure that it
does using the same default as the playbooks/group_vars.

Change-Id: I451ffd029c73b2d0613f53b7b4e21f38e43d3d7c
'}]
commit_message:
MNAIO: Ensure consistent defaults

The DNS_NAMESERVER environment variable in the service
setup script does not have a default. We ensure that it
does using the same default as the playbooks/group_vars.

Change-Id: I451ffd029c73b2d0613f53b7b4e21f38e43d3d7c

The DATA_DISK_DEVICE environment variable no longer exists.
In this patch we correct the README with the appropriate
instructions for changing the data disk device.

Change-Id: I2790b6d848a2960d89f122b0f5bb1cf714c68809

commit_message:
MNAIO: Correct README regarding DATA_DISK_DEVICE

The DATA_DISK_DEVICE environment variable no longer exists.
In this patch we correct the README with the appropriate
instructions for changing the data disk device.

Change-Id: I2790b6d848a2960d89f122b0f5bb1cf714c68809

Adding support for using vSphere template as a volume
snapshot format in vCenter server. The current format
(COW disk) does not allow snapshot of attached volumes
and this limitation is removed by the new template
format.

Change-Id: Id5dd71a785c4cd72ba44f9b4d26319be53079c39

commit_message:
VMware: Use vSphere template as snapshot format

Adding support for using vSphere template as a volume
snapshot format in vCenter server. The current format
(COW disk) does not allow snapshot of attached volumes
and this limitation is removed by the new template
format.

Change-Id: Id5dd71a785c4cd72ba44f9b4d26319be53079c39
(cherry picked from commit f36fc239804fb8fbf57d9df0320e2cb6d315ea10)

commit_message:
Spec: Kolla-managed backup (and restore) for MariaDB

This mini-spec documents an approach for how Kolla-triggered and managed
MariaDB backups might be handled.

Change-Id: I65f1ab92b9dce48cdd752fffd2123bd58d65b98f
bp: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/kolla/+spec/database-backup-recovery

subject: Add support specify volume type when boot instance
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 3189, 'name': 'Chet Burgess', 'email': 'cfb@metacloud.com', 'username': 'cfb-n'}, {'_account_id': 4393, 'name': 'Dan Smith', 'email': 'dms@danplanet.com', 'username': 'danms'}, {'_account_id': 5754, 'name': 'Alex Xu', 'email': 'hejie.xu@intel.com', 'username': 'xuhj'}, {'_account_id': 6873, 'name': 'Matt Riedemann', 'email': 'mriedem.os@gmail.com', 'username': 'mriedem'}, {'_account_id': 12408, 'name': 'Maxim Nestratov', 'email': 'mnestratov@virtuozzo.com', 'username': 'mnestratov'}, {'_account_id': 13630, 'name': 'Luo Gangyi', 'email': 'luogangyi@corp.netease.com', 'username': 'luogangyi'}, {'_account_id': 15888, 'name': 'Zhenyu Zheng', 'email': 'zheng.zhenyu@outlook.com', 'username': 'Kevin_Zheng'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22378, 'name': 'Kaiyuan Qi', 'email': 'qiky@inspur.com', 'username': 'qiky'}, {'_account_id': 23312, 'name': 'kangyufei', 'email': 'kangyf@inspur.com', 'username': 'kangyufei'}, {'_account_id': 24454, 'name': 'suguangfeng', 'email': 'suguangfeng@inspur.com', 'username': 'suguangfeng'}, {'_account_id': 26458, 'name': 'Brin Zhang', 'email': 'zhangbailin@inspur.com', 'username': 'zhangbailin'}, {'_account_id': 26490, 'name': 'Jason SUN', 'email': 'sunjia@inspur.com', 'username': 'sunjia'}, {'_account_id': 27190, 'name': 'Leopard Ma', 'email': 'mabao@inspur.com', 'username': 'LeopardMa'}, {'_account_id': 27594, 'name': 'Jie Li', 'email': 'lijie@unitedstack.com', 'username': 'ramboman'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2018-07-02 11:22:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2018-07-02 11:33:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2018-07-03 01:31:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 26490, 'date': '2018-07-03 10:01:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 27190, 'date': '2018-07-03 10:03:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 24454, 'date': '2018-07-03 10:04:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 23312, 'date': '2018-07-03 10:08:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-07-06 14:37:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

We've already rejected this same blueprint at least half a dozen times. Search launchpad for nova blueprints about specifying a volume type when creating a server, you'll probably find a few with links to others (and maybe mailing list threads).

See the policy on no more orchestration:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/contributor/project-scope.html#no-more-orchestration

If users want a non-default volume type when booting from volume, they can create the volume in cinder using a specific type and then provider that volume to nova."}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2018-07-06 15:51:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thank you for your review, we think this is a good proposal,mainly the following:
1.This method can be used to create an instance of the specified volume type, only need to call the nova api once;
2.From the perspective of the user:If you have multiple storage backends and create instances of different OSs, you need to use image to specify a volume type to create a bootable volume, and then use the volume to start the instance. If you need to create an instance on a different storage backend, then You need to use the image to specify the volume type to create a volume multiple times. Such an experience is undoubtedly painful.
3.This way, although the API can be combined on the UI, it is undoubtedly inefficient.
4.As discussed by irc, we reserve the application, and conduct further research and consider this issue.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-07-06 19:12:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

A quick search for 'volume type' in nova blueprints in Launchpad found these duplicate blueprints:

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/support-boot-instance-set-store-type

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/support-volume-type-with-bdm-parameter

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/vol-type-with-blank-vol

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/volume-support-for-multi-hypervisors

And the openstack-dev mailing list thread I started the last time a spec was proposed for this same feature:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-May/117242.html"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-07-09 14:05:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

As Matt has said, Nova is not an orchestration system. Either have the user select a volume_type in Horizon when they create the volume or create the volume with the openstackclient and specify a volume type then.

Nova will only be accepting a volume identifier to the boot command. That's it.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 12408, 'date': '2018-07-09 16:13:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Nova indeed is not an orchestration system but it supports bdm_v2 natively, does it? Is this API going to be deprecated? If not, maybe it's reasonable to add a way to extend it? I would put additional key for volume list in BDM v2 and it woudn't cost much."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-07-09 16:27:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Nova indeed is not an orchestration system but it supports bdm_v2
 > natively, does it? Is this API going to be deprecated? If not,
 > maybe it's reasonable to add a way to extend it? I would put
 > additional key for volume list in BDM v2 and it woudn't cost much.

Hi Maxim,

I'm not quite following you. What does the BDMv2 representation have to do with volume type being supplied in the nova boot command?

In general, we do not want to have any more proxy APIs in Nova. The place for volume attributes is in Cinder.

Best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 12408, 'date': '2018-07-09 16:31:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi Jay, I meant this https://docs.openstack.org/nova/queens/user/block-device-mapping.html#block-device-mapping-v2'}, {'account_id': 13630, 'date': '2018-07-25 09:23:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

4 years, still no progress!
Why refuse a truly useful function just by so-called design philosophy？
I think a good design should  care more about user experience rather than programmer, am I right?'}, {'account_id': 12408, 'date': '2018-07-25 09:35:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2018-08-16 07:04:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2018-08-17 01:47:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 27594, 'date': '2018-09-06 02:13:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-09-09 19:42:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I've long been a proponent of the "no more proxy APIs" argument, and I still am. I've shared in the NAKing of this in the past. I don't think nova is an orchestrator, nor is it good at orchestrating things, and I don't want to go back on any of these policies.

However, I'm starting to reconsider my opinion on this one issue because it is so often requested and I do see the utility of it. I think that part of the concern here is that despite this being a hugely popular request for a nearly inconsequential extra flag on boot, it *could* lead to an influx of additional proxy requests, both for storage and network, if not other things.

I think that we've demonstrated our ability to successfully reject new proxy APIs, both for this feature and others, even in the face of counter examples from earlier in our history (like the fact that we orchestrate creation of volumes at all in nova) and new proxies we've approved which we for some reason feel are different (like the mirroring of aggregates to placement for admin convenience). I think that given the weight that this one feature has for so many people, it's probably time we reconsider allowing it into Nova as a pragmatic exception to the unchanged rule of "no more proxy APIs". It's just too minor of a thing with too many people demanding it to consider holding fast to the idealistic rule I think.

Just MHO.

/me dons flak jacket'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-10 04:59:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> It's just too minor of a thing with too many people demanding it to consider holding fast to the idealistic rule I think.

That's why I threw it on the Stein PTG agenda to talk about it again, because it won't go away and I'm tired of being beaten over the head as an "unreasonable nova maintainer". In other words, I'm losing the energy to say no to this anymore.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-13 21:13:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

There was agreement at the Stein PTG to move forward with this feature, see the details in the etherpad:

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/nova-ptg-stein

There will be some things from there which require documenting in the spec, like how to handle image-defined BDMs and volume-backed snapshots with respect to the volume type, and also upgrade impacts.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-13 21:27:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(19 comments)'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2018-09-14 06:21:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(18 comments)'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2018-09-14 06:26:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2018-09-14 06:54:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Patch Set 5 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2018-09-14 07:10:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2018-09-14 07:56:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2018-09-14 08:18:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-17 14:09:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Soft -1 for just adding some more details, but overall I think this is OK, it's a pretty straight-forward change. I'll discuss with Dan Smith and if it's OK with what I've suggested inline, I'll just make the updates myself (since Brin is probably done for the day)."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-17 14:42:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-17 14:43:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

(2 comments)

I added more detail to the proposed change section and also fleshed out the specific tests I'd want to see at a minimum."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-09-17 14:49:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-17 14:58:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-09-17 14:59:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2

Let's do it."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-17 15:00:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-17 15:00:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 3189, 'date': '2018-09-17 15:10:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1

Giving my +1 just for historical purposes. After all this has been my favorite dead horse to flog for at least the past 2 years. Glad to see its finally got support. Thank all!'}, {'account_id': 12408, 'date': '2018-09-17 15:35:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2018-09-25 13:20:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-25 16:20:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(1 comment)'}]

commit_message:
Add support specify volume type when boot instance

This blueprint proposes adding support for specifying
"volume_type" when booting instances.

APIImpact

bp: boot-instance-specific-storage-backend
Change-Id: Id1724e69c26478f62673caac3595ff9f5e5be173

[{'account_id': 9592, 'date': '2018-09-24 19:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9592, 'date': '2018-09-24 19:12:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9592, 'date': '2018-09-25 03:21:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 10112, 'date': '2018-09-25 03:24:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Why?'}, {'account_id': 9592, 'date': '2018-09-25 03:28:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

They were never designed for upstream ci, they take way too long. Validations are for 3rd party only.  We are dying on timeouts, please let this go through.'}, {'account_id': 12393, 'date': '2018-09-25 05:43:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 27898, 'date': '2018-09-25 05:54:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

If they are not desgined for upstream ci and does not give us any value those 15 minutes are gold to us right now.'}, {'account_id': 28223, 'date': '2018-09-25 06:22:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Not really sure this is the right thing to do - how do we check if all is deployed as expected? Commit message needs some more explanations on that I think.'}, {'account_id': 8449, 'date': '2018-09-25 07:18:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

> Not really sure this is the right thing to do - how do we check if
 > all is deployed as expected? Commit message needs some more
 > explanations on that I think.

o/ because timeouts are killing us - there is more info in the bug'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-09-25 08:15:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I think we should keep the validations framework tested in upstream CI.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-09-25 08:16:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Although I agree with "If they are not desgined for upstream ci and does not give us any value those 15 minutes are gold to us right now"'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-09-25 12:02:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

Given the current situation and the issues we're having with timeouts. I think it's a good idea to disable these, and keep testing them in OVB instead of multinode. Either way, Wes is right, we are not actually taking these into account and they are taking a varying amount of time which does impact us. We can talk about this further on IRC."}, {'account_id': 9592, 'date': '2018-09-25 12:22:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

I'll try to walk through why validations are not meant for upstream CI.  First of all the resources we use upstream DO NOT MEET tripleo requirements for a deployment, and WILL ALWAYS FAIL.  The disk size, memory, provided by upstream do not match http://tripleo.org/install/environments/baremetal.html#minimum-system-requirements

When validation errors are found, they are ignored in upstream jobs because of the above
http://logs.openstack.org/81/563881/2/check/tripleo-ci-centos-7-containers-multinode/80b990d/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-09-23_19_22_55_208761

http://logs.openstack.org/81/563881/2/check/tripleo-ci-centos-7-containers-multinode/80b990d/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/failed_tripleo_validations.log.txt.gz

The value vs. potential time spent in validations is NOT appropriate for upstream.  This kind of testing is better suited for 3rd party ovb or libvirt testing where requirements can be met for tripleo"}, {'account_id': 28223, 'date': '2018-09-25 12:24:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

Fine for me - thanks for the details!'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2018-09-25 12:31:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-09-25 12:47:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-09-25 12:47:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 10112, 'date': '2018-09-25 13:37:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I'm fine with this after comments, but I still think this needs better commit message."}, {'account_id': 10112, 'date': '2018-09-25 13:48:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Code-Review'}]

Let's be explicit about ensuring these tasks are off

Closes-Bug: #1794034

commit_message:
Run all tasks through the threadpool

We have support for handling async tasks in the task manager and
tracking their rate limiting at task start time. Extend this to
everything, even the sync calls.

Change-Id: I33325fb5be21264df0a68ceef2202ab7875f63ec

commit_message:
Normalize image when using PUT on Glance v2

When Glance v2 was used, the created image was not being normalized,
which doesn't help end users on having a consistent representation of
the resource regardless the cloud configuration choices.

Story: #2003735
Task: #26401

Change-Id: I197762c0e31ccff9cf6fd6a2f9f2ae6174ad36d1

commit_message:
Make root partition size configurable

With the previous commits in this series, this can now be configured on
a per pxe server group basis; but default to all VMs with the same root
partition size works fine for me.

Change-Id: Idb82466ca887466d3babe2da6998b057e99f676c

commit_message:
Enable setting mnaio disk size by pxe server group

Also, halve the loadbalancer default disk size; this is the only group
I'm somewhat confident doesn't need 90 GB of disk.

Change-Id: I40b46c8d978cdefbed8c4cd5586c7ded0fe318dc

commit_message:
Use group vars to reduce redundancy in host vars

This is essentially a noop that establishes a healthy DRY pattern of
group var definitions in the pxe_server subgroups.

Change-Id: Ie458f0684f720879c21ca639320814ef12d5dc4e

commit_message:
Change VM definition in deploy-vm mnaio playbook

... to allow usage of host vars and group vars by looping the part of
the play that reifies the VM templates over pxe_servers rather than
vm_hosts. Instead of looping over pxe_servers hosts on each task, loop
over and delegate to vm_hosts on each task.

What this makes possible is the definition of default_vm_storage on a
per-host basis. The specific use case I have in mind is to allocate a
larger share of VG space to compute nodes without artificially limiting
how much space the compute nodes can have by bloating every other VM
in proportion.

Change-Id: I5f9a14038d59af7740acb64cce7f83fd88e5555a

[{'created': '2018-05-09 15:18:48.000000000', 'message': "Skip ServerActionsTestJSON.test_rebuild_server for cells v1 job

This is another occurrence of a rebuild test randomly timing out
waiting for status changes in the cells v1 job, so blacklist it.
Cells v1 is deprecated and should be gone soon anyway, so we don't
need to waste time hitting stuff like this.

Change-Id: Icb1d33c6e602467e21efe4838cb6edbadab14834
Related-Bug: #1709985
"}]
commit_message:
Skip ServerActionsTestJSON.test_rebuild_server for cells v1 job

This is another occurrence of a rebuild test randomly timing out
waiting for status changes in the cells v1 job, so blacklist it.
Cells v1 is deprecated and should be gone soon anyway, so we don't
need to waste time hitting stuff like this.

Change-Id: Icb1d33c6e602467e21efe4838cb6edbadab14834
Related-Bug: #1709985

commit_message:
Translate security group rules.

This commit handles the creation of security group rules out from k8s
network policies. It currently supports both egress and ingress rules.

Driver unit tests will be added in a follow-up patch as the driver
itself will still be modified in the series.

Partially-Implements: bp/k8s-network-policies
Change-Id: Ief415e3663cb9d46831291e15a06fca79d920ee9
Signed-off-by: Daniel Mellado <dmellado@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove external_network_bridge Neutron option

Config option "external_network_bridge" in Neutron was deprecated
in Ocata cycle.
Now it is going to be removed completly with [1].
Background of the deprecation and removal is described in [2].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/567369/
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-September/134859.html

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/567369/
Change-Id: Id0fd1dc83f3b99da567078375a0eee90c4dd0f56

[{'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2018-07-13 13:02:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-07-13 13:02:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2018-07-13 13:04:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2018-07-16 13:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2018-07-16 13:47:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2018-07-16 13:50:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-07-23 16:52:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

Very neat and readable!

Thanks for that welcomed addition!

Do you mind adding extra tests to make sure the --diff option would output the expected dictionary, please?'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2018-07-24 14:13:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2018-07-25 18:15:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-08-01 15:47:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2018-08-01 15:55:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8: Patch Set 7 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-08-01 16:30:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2018-08-02 19:32:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2018-08-02 19:36:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-08-08 13:56:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-08-08 13:57:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

To make sure this still works with delegation, additional tests should be added.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-08-08 13:59:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

I think if you want to determine if things really have changed, the copy part of the action plugin should already do so.

if the ordering of key/values pair have changed, that shouldn't affect things if we simply sort all the keys going forward. That looks simpler to do, if not done already."}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2018-08-08 14:29:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2018-08-08 14:37:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Yes I believe the sorting is already implemented.  So the edge case this would resolve is applying the config_template module for the first time with overrides that do not change any configuration.  In that scenario the config would be re-ordered and the copy module would mark it as changed.

This change is also meant to provide a detailed diff of what should be in your config_overrides if you are not expecting any changes.  For ceph we are using this functionality to check for configuration changes in diff mode first before taking over a cluster with ceph-ansible.  The expectation is that if you have configured your variables correctly you should be able to take over a cluster without restarting services.  We want to avoid any and all unnecessary restarts.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-08-09 11:23:59.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review-1 by Jean-Philippe Evrard <jean-philippe@evrard.me>
'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-08-09 11:24:00.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review0 by Jean-Philippe Evrard <jean-philippe@evrard.me>
'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2018-08-10 14:11:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2018-09-04 19:35:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2018-09-06 13:18:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2018-09-06 13:23:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-09-24 16:30:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2018-09-24 17:20:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Patch Set 13 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2018-09-25 00:09:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15: Patch Set 14 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-09-25 15:08:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Compare dict vars to determine changed

Compare dict vars of before and after configuration to determine whether
the config keys or values have changed so a configuration file will not
be incorrectly marked as changed when only the ordering has changed.

Set diff return variable to a dict of changes applied.

Change-Id: Ie67119b1420936c8ed89f8338ea9dce4c47e185c

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-25 11:30:37.000000000', 'message': "Add tags for beats setup tasks

Previously the beat setup tasks were tagged with 'setup' but the include
statements were not, so the tasks were always skipped when using '--tags
setup'. This change adds tags to the includes so that the tasks are executed
as expected

Change-Id: If16069cd273d84a22b229b8140e5a8d56eed86d1
"}]
commit_message:
Add tags for beats setup tasks

Previously the beat setup tasks were tagged with 'setup' but the include
statements were not, so the tasks were always skipped when using '--tags
setup'. This change adds tags to the includes so that the tasks are executed
as expected

Change-Id: If16069cd273d84a22b229b8140e5a8d56eed86d1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-25 02:54:02.000000000', 'message': 'Convert refresh fact to strings

While the use of "to_json" resulted in a string it also created a JSON
escaped a string full of slashes which then corrupts kibana index patterns.

Change-Id: I2c26ab9dd4930226f3e554c2f9bed5e382cdafa5
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Convert refresh fact to strings

While the use of "to_json" resulted in a string it also created a JSON
escaped a string full of slashes which then corrupts kibana index patterns.

Change-Id: I2c26ab9dd4930226f3e554c2f9bed5e382cdafa5
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

subject: Fix journalbeat installation for mixed environments
messages: [{'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2018-09-25 11:35:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-09-25 15:05:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-25 11:35:10.000000000', 'message': 'Fix journalbeat installation for mixed environments

The previous code would terminate the play immediatley if any hosts
in the environment did not have a journal directory. This change runs
the journalbeat install role selectively on hosts that have the journal
directory, and skips hosts that do not.

In addition a legacy task to stop the play after uninstallation is removed,
this functionality is currently broken.

Change-Id: I412e3594c4b2292caafafb580bb4ede9ccfd3944
'}]
commit_message:
Fix journalbeat installation for mixed environments

The previous code would terminate the play immediatley if any hosts
in the environment did not have a journal directory. This change runs
the journalbeat install role selectively on hosts that have the journal
directory, and skips hosts that do not.

In addition a legacy task to stop the play after uninstallation is removed,
this functionality is currently broken.

Change-Id: I412e3594c4b2292caafafb580bb4ede9ccfd3944

found some unversioned links in the Helm documentation which are pointing to the latest OpenStack Configuration Guide. So it's easier to support a latest-link for that, instead changing the links in the project docs. Maybe there are more such kind use cases."}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-09-16 16:55:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Remove inspecting state support from inspect_hardware

Returning INSPECTING state from InspectInterface.inspect_hardware
was deprecated and removed in this patch.

This also removed the deprecated configuration option
[conductor]inspect_timeout.

Change-Id: I636e11a80451aa3a44d7f4b30295257d57028c34
Story: #1725211
Task: #26177

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-12 09:07:04.000000000', 'message': 'Match IKEv2 state PARENT SA

While using IKE policy with version v2,
the IPsec siteconnection status always down.
From the log show ipsec connection had already established,
but we did not match that state.

From librewan wiki[1], an established IKEv2 connection
will output "PARENT SA established", this patch adds it.

[1] https://libreswan.org/wiki/How_to_read_status_output

Change-Id: Iffff7d00f48e69fbc53bb45df17d6a5be6760a6d
Closes-Bug: #1781354
'}, {'created': '2018-08-08 15:08:23.000000000', 'message': 'Match IPSEC SA established state

While using IKE policy with version v2,
the IPsec siteconnection status always down.
From librewan wiki[1], the "parse2" in IKEv2 mistakenly
calls itself a PARENT SA which same as "parse1",
This is a known bug for some versions of libreswan.

For the newer versions of libreswan(3.20+),
the "IPsec SA established" will successful output if
phase2 state established.

Here we match the "established" and "newest IPSEC" for
an established IPSEC SA.

[1] https://libreswan.org/wiki/How_to_read_status_output

Change-Id: Iffff7d00f48e69fbc53bb45df17d6a5be6760a6d
Closes-Bug: #1781354
'}, {'created': '2018-08-14 03:11:52.000000000', 'message': 'Match IPSEC SA established state

While using IKE policy with version v2,
the IPsec siteconnection status always down.
From librewan wiki[1], the "phase2" in IKEv2 mistakenly
calls itself a PARENT SA which same as "phase1",
This is a known bug for some versions of libreswan.

For the newer versions of libreswan(3.20+),
the "IPsec SA established" will successful output if
phase2 state established.

Here we match the "established" and "newest IPSEC" for
an established IPSEC SA.

[1] https://libreswan.org/wiki/How_to_read_status_output

Change-Id: Iffff7d00f48e69fbc53bb45df17d6a5be6760a6d
Closes-Bug: #1781354
'}]
commit_message:
Match IPSEC SA established state

While using IKE policy with version v2,
the IPsec siteconnection status always down.
From librewan wiki[1], the "phase2" in IKEv2 mistakenly
calls itself a PARENT SA which same as "phase1",
This is a known bug for some versions of libreswan.

For the newer versions of libreswan(3.20+),
the "IPsec SA established" will successful output if
phase2 state established.

Here we match the "established" and "newest IPSEC" for
an established IPSEC SA.

[1] https://libreswan.org/wiki/How_to_read_status_output

Change-Id: Iffff7d00f48e69fbc53bb45df17d6a5be6760a6d
Closes-Bug: #1781354

commit_message:
Move os-faults jobs to project repository

Similar to official projects almost all of Zuul configuration is moved
to project repo. The only remaining job is publish-to-pypy [1].

Corresponding import patch is already merged into os-faults repo [2].

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/creators.html#central-config-exceptions
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/602578/
    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/600011/

Change-Id: I84988d8f682f9b555b260a0929c0092d84a727b7

commit_message:
ignore Editor tags

Without this patch, if you use something like ctags, your
git status will always show 'tags' in red.

Change-Id: I7c6c8d40935fc78dc328a11900797818d6d6f094

Remove the unnecessary note message

when configure network node, there's no external_network_bridge
option to configure, so the note is unnecessary.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-25 07:12:02.000000000', 'message': 'api-ref: Fix wrong bold decoration

In the 'DELETE /os-floating-ips/{floating_ip_id}' API,
"Error response codes: badRequest(400), unauthorized(401),
forbidden(403)," is bold.
But it should not be bold.
So fix it.

TrivialFix
Change-Id: Ic2d1ae2856406600c9dd3273d21dd2f18e56c1e9
'}]
commit_message:
api-ref: Fix wrong bold decoration

In the 'DELETE /os-floating-ips/{floating_ip_id}' API,
"Error response codes: badRequest(400), unauthorized(401),
forbidden(403)," is bold.
But it should not be bold.
So fix it.

TrivialFix
Change-Id: Ic2d1ae2856406600c9dd3273d21dd2f18e56c1e9

commit_message:
Add swift as gnocchi storage option

 - Uses swift if swift is enabled.
 - Uses ceph if ceph is enabled.
 - Defaults to file if swift and ceph are enabled.
   Explicitly set to swift or ceph when both are enabled.
 - Include swift client detail in storage section of gnocchi conf

Change-Id: I78df9a2fbe546038e1d6df350d8db0fd9b6f6d49
